editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: Libellus Orthographicus: OR, The diligent School-boy's DIRECTORY.
Being certain plain and profitable Dialogue-wise-placed Rules and Directions, for the better Unstanding of (especially) the English-orthography.
By Thomas Hunt, Mr. of Arts of Pembroke Colledge in Oxford, and School-Master at St. Dunstans in the East.
div.q: Quint. Perveniri ad summum, nisi ex principiis, non potest.
div.p: LONDON: Printed by T. Johnson, and are to be sold by John Hancock at the first shop of Popes-Head Alley in Cornhil, and Francis Cossinet at the Anchor and Mariner in Tower-street. 1661.

div.head: To the much Honor'd Sir Laurence Bromfield Knight and Colonel, all Heath and Happiness.
div.p:
ALthough the Piece I now present you, as it is in its self, and as it may relate to you, be but a weak and worthless Work: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; not at all worthy your view, even in
the least: yet, quale quale est, since at the earnest request of some, that are well-wishers to the publike, I am somewhat encouraged to be (though unwillingly) willing therewith to trouble the Press a little; Let me a little press you to the trouble, so far (I beseech you) as to accept of its Patronage; which, that you may the less unwillingly accept of, I can assure you, no St. Peters Bonds abide is here, that is,
nothing that tends, either to Schism in Church, or Sedition in State.

VVere it (I confess) such an one as Aelian's Tacticks, a Discourse of ordering and embattelling an Army, of ranking of Soldiers, a something de Arte Militaria, or so, perchance it might a little please you (Sir) my special, good, and onely true Friend, as being in some small measure Opus par Patrono: But being onely certain
DIALOGUES of ordering the Alphabet, of ranking of Syllables, a something de Arte Li • eraria, and the like; I presume it will profit your Grand-childe, my towardly Scholar; he being (had this been directed to him) altogether Patronus par operi. And in very deed for his sake, (a something to shew my thankfulness, for the many undeserv'd favors received from you, and by your means from others,)
was it first thought on: for his sake, (to use Homers expression, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) first, though crassa Minerva rudely (as we say) penn'd, and now at last publish't.

But whatsoever it be, such as it is, thus penn'd, thus publish'd, your protection is humbly pray'd, at leastwise your courteous Acceptance thereof: for although Chrysippus his 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 holds not good here; this being (as I have already confessed)
none of the best, and therefore not at all praise-worthy: yet since there is in it something that may benefit your Sonne and other young Scholars; yea Apprentices, and some others also; provided they be not altogether 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , your courteous Acceptance (in my esteem, hujus, quicquid est scriptiunculae, Genius) will put a value on, and plena manu (as we say) sufficiently crown both it, and me its
Author; who am exceedingly glad of this opportunity, to witness to you, yea, and to our English-world too, (so far as I am able) how deeply I am

closer.signed: Your most engaged friend, and most ready servant; Thomas Hunt.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
VVHat was more than twenty years ago by the by, (onely as a by-work) practised among my weaker minor-Scholars in private, I now take the boldness to print for the publike. Many of my abler then-Scholars (now Fathers of children, I had almost said Grand-fathers) by their often (and that very lately too) in my hearing, lovingly and likingly repeating what I did to
then, have (in part) put me upon what I do now; of which, if any be well-done, 'tis well, if otherwise, let me be blamed for the failings, censured for the faults; yet so blamed, so censured (I beseech thee) as that I be not altogether discouraged to amend what's amiss: if this (now blushingly exposed to publike view) chance to have the happiness to deserve a Reimpression: in the mean while I remain thine,

div.head: Gratulatory ex-tempore Verses of three, quondam-Scholars to T. H.

div.l: BAd times, bad Books, most commonly produce;
Times better, better Books, of better use:
And now (if any) trust me! this is one
Deserves Youth's commendations: for 'tis none
Of those that slily teach boys, youth, & men
Rebelliously to handle Pike, or Pen.
This, this hint's Loyalty; this, this is good,
And Hunt's, hunt's not for praise, (much less) for blood.
Accept it then; upon it (School-boy) pore;
For, for Orthography thou needst no more;
And since, like This, none extant was before,
'Tis worth thy pains to read it o're & o're.
REader, this School-boy's Directory's none
Of the THE Directory: that was one,
(Though for a while, the same some did • dore)
Just worth three farthings twice told, and no more:
Of more worth's this by far; this, this is one
Learns all to spell all, but Rebellion.
May't prosper then! And, as by it before
I better'd was, so now let thousands more.
ALl sorts of words this little Book spells: none
Excepted are, onely Rebellion.
Since then 'tis loyal, carp not at it, (Sir!)
Lest (like T. H.) it prove a Sufferer.

div.head: T. H. his School-boyes to MOMUS.
div.l: MOmus! since this small Book will profit us,
Commend it, or come mend it, O Momus!
Wilt not? Canst frown? frown then, for thy frown more
Commends it than thy smile can: frown therefore.

div.head: Libellus Orthographicus: Or, The School boy's Directory.
DIALOGUE I. Adam, Benjamin. Of Orthography.

p.hi: BEn. what Book is that?
Libellus Orthographicus.
Why is it call'd so?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: Because it containeth Rules for the better understanding of Orthography.

p.hi: What is Orthography?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Orthography is that part of Grammar that teacheth with what Letters any word is to be spell'd.

p.hi: How many things doth it treat of?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Four things.

p.hi: Which be they?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: First Letters, Secondly Syllables, (to which I shall also ad Words. Thirdly, Right utterance. And fourthly, Points of sentences▪ of all which in their order.

p.hi: First then of the first, to wit. Letters.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Of letters, see the following-Dialogue.

div.head: DIALOGUE II. Charls, David. Of letters in general.

p.hi: DAvid what is a letter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Honest Charls, a letter is the least part of a word

p.hi: How many letters are there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Twenty four.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Name them.

p.hi: A b c d e f g h i k l m n o p q r s t u w x y z.
How many things belong to every letter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Three things.

p.hi: Which be they?

list.item: 1. Name whereby it's call'd.
2. Figure whereby it's known.
3 Force whereby it's pronounc'd.

p.hi: What are made of letters?
Syllables.
What of Syllables?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Words.

p.hi: What of words?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A speech, which is either prose, or verse.

p.hi: How many waies are letters distinguished?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two waies, according to 1. shape, 2. sound.

p.hi: Let us hear what can be said of letters distinguished according to their shape?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That you shall, but because Emanuel and Francis have undertaken that task, I shall leave it to them to discourse of.

div.head: DIALOGUE III. Emanuel, Francis. Of letters distinguished according to shape.

p.hi: FRancis, how are letters distinguished according to their shape?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: First into great, as A, B, C, or secondly small as a b c.

p.hi: When must we write great letters? when small?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: We must write great letters in the beginning of,
I. Sentences, as Fear God, Honor the King:

II. Proper names as Henry, Thomas, Severn, Oxford: to which we may ad also names of
1. Arts, as Grammar, Logick.
2. Trades, as Clothier, Sadler.
3. Offices, as Bishop, Major.
4. Dignities, as Majesty, Highness.
III. The more eminent words of sentences, as this of Calvin's:

Never did man truely fear God, but he likewise honor'd the King: here the more eminent words, to wit, God, and King, are written with
great letters, as you see: also that of Quarles's: Durable is that State where Aaron commands the people, and where Moses commands Aaron: but m • st happy in the continuance, where God commands both: here State, Aaron, Moses, God are written also with great letters.

4. Every verse in a Poem; as,
May we all live more loyal and more true,
To give to Caesar and to God their due.

p.hi: Now I perceive that the beginning of sentences of proper names, of the more eminent words of sentences, and lastly of every verse are written with great letters; but (friend,) concerning proper names, are there many kindes of them?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yea, as the names 1. of heathenish Gods, Jupiter, Neptune, 2. Men Charls, James. 3. Rivers, Thames, Avon. 4 Winds, East-wind, North-wind, of which there are 32 according to the Sea mans Card. 5. Moneths, which are 12. in number, as you know. 6. Heathenish Goddesses, Juno, Venus. 7. Women, Alice, Mary. 8. Cities, London, Worcester. 9. Islands, Britain, Cyprus: 10. Countries, France, Spain▪ these ten are all proper names, and therefore must be written with great letters.

p.hi: What say you to all other names or words?

sp.speaker: F
sp.p: I say that all other words are commonly written with small letters.

p.hi:
When great letters are set alone, or but few together, what do they signifie, o •
stand sometime for?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: They stand sometimes,
1. For whole words, so M. T. C. stand for Mark, Tully, Cicero, L for Lord, LL. for Lords, B. for Bishop▪ BB. for Bishops; or,
2. For a Number, so (I) standeth for one, (V) for five, (X) ten (L) fifty, (C) an hundred, (D five hundred, (M) a thousand, and all these are called numeral letters.

p.hi: What doth a lesser numeral letter (placed before a greater) take away?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: It taketh away just so much as it is in its self, so (i) set before (v) as thus (iv) makes four.

p.hi: What doth it, being set after?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ad so much as it is in its self, so (i) set after (v) thus (vi) maketh six: after (x) thus (xi) eleven.

p.hi: If a cros-line be made over a numeral letter, what doth it imply?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Thousands, so a cros-line over v̄ is five thousand, over x̄ ten thousand and so of the rest.

p.hi: So much of Letters distinguished according to their shape; can you say any thing of letters distinguished according to their sound?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yes, that I can, but I shall leave that to George and Henry, the two next speakers.

div.head: DIALOGUE IV. George, Henry. Of letters distinguished according to sound.

p.hi: Henry, how are letters distinguished according to their sound▪

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Into 1. vowels, (of which are made dipththongs) or 2. consonants.

p.hi: How are consonants divided?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Into 1. Mutes, or 2 half-vowels.

p.hi: How are half-vowels divided?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Into 1. liquids, or 2. double-consonants.

p.hi: Your distinguishing of letters thus according to their sound, I like very well, but hear me one word.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Well, I hear you, say on.

p.hi: Shall we have any thing of all these, to wit, of vowels, dipththongs, consonants, and the rest, as they lye in their order?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Yea, you shall have a Dialogue of each one of them.

p.hi: Your Dialogue then of vowels in the first place.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Attend to James and Kellam.

div.head: DIALOGUE V. James, Kellam. Of Vowels.

p.hi: PLay-fellow what is a vowel?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: A vowel is a letter which maketh a full and perfect sound of its self.

p.hi: How many vowels are there?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Five, to wit, a, e, i, o, u, to which also is added the greek vowel (y)

p.hi: Are a, e, i, o, u, alwaies vowels?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: No, for (i) and (u) in the same syllable, placed either before themselves, or other vowels, are consonants.

p.hi: How are they written when they are vowels? how when consonants?

sp.speaker: K
sp.p: When vowels thus, (i, u,) when consonants thus, (j v.)

p.hi: Are (j) and (v) when they are consonants, set before all the vowels?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Yea.

p.hi: Your example of (j)
Ja, je, ji, jo▪ ju: jack, jet, jig, jog, jug.
Your example of (v.)

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Va, ve, vi, vo, vu: vast, verse, vine, vomit▪ vulgar, also (y) is a consonant when it is placed before a, e, o, as ya, ye, yo▪ yate, yet, yoak.

p.hi: But tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: What is it?

p.hi: When j, and y are consonants, are they sounded alike?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: No; for (j) before a, e, o, makes jack, jet, jog, as you have heard even now: but y before them makes yate, yet, yoak, and that is the reason why (yet) differs so from ( • et) as to jet up and down.

p.hi: But what say you of y, as also of w, coming after a, e, o?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: I say that (y) as also (w) coming after a, e, o, become vowels, and make diphthongs, as ay, ey, oy, aw, ew, ow.

p.hi: What more?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: That y, is never set before (i) or (u) therefore I said even now, ya, ye, yo, leaving out (i) and (u); also that (w) never comes before (u).

p.hi: But by your favour, (y) doth sometimes come before (i), as this word (yield) can witness.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: True, in this word (y) cometh before (i) but you must take notice, that the found of (ee) in that word is expressed by (ie) so is it also in shield, field, and in many other such like words.

p.hi: To go on then, have you any thing else to say of y, and w?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Onely this, that after (i) neither (w) nor (y) can stand in the same syllable; nor after (u) neither, except (v) become a consonant, and (y) a vowel; as to vy, with any one: the word vy here makes it good.

p.hi: Now let's hear the Dialogue of dipththongs, Kellam.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: You shall Iames, but it must be out of the mouths of Luke and Michael.

div.head: DIALOGUE VI. Luke, Michael. Of Dipththongs.

p.hi: MIchael, how are dipththongs made?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Of the vowels diversly placed.

p.hi: Will any two vowels make a dipththong?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No, i, and u, before any vowels will not make dipththongs.

p.hi: Why so?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because they must either, 1 be separated, as in this word pi-ety: i, is separated from (e); or else 2. they must be turned into consonants, as in this word in-vent (v) is a consonant; or 3. one of the vowels is but little sounded, so we sound (u) but very little in these words, guidance, guide, guift, and the like.

p.hi: What vowels then coming before other vowels will make dipththongs?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: These three, to wit, a, e, o, set before (i) make ai, ei, oi, set before (u) au, eu, ou.

p.hi: But ae, oe, are dipthongs, and yet there is neither (i) nor (u) in them.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: These are dipththongs 'tis true, but such that are onely used in Latine: as (aetas) with ae, coelum with (oe) and in some few english words borrowed from the Greek as oeconomy, &c.

p.hi: What is a dipththong?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A dipththong is the sound of two vowels in one syllable.

p.hi: How are dipththongs divided?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Into 1 six, perfect or proper, as ai, ei, oi, au eu, ou: or 2 four imperfect or improper, as ea, ee, oa, oo

p.hi: What is the difference betwixt perfect, and imperfect dipththongs?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: This, in perfect d • pththongs both the vowels make a perfect sound; but in the imperfect ones, one of the vowels is but little sounded.

p.hi: What vowels (set before others) do make the four imperfect dipththongs?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: These two vowels (e and o.)

p.hi: As how, I pray?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: (e) set before (a) maketh (ea), before it self (ee) so (o) before (a) maketh (oa), before it self (oo,) and so you have the four imperfect dipthongs, ea, ee, oa, oo.

p.hi: But 'twas said before (as I remember) that (y) and (w) coming after a, e, o, became vowels, and so made these dipththongs, to wit, ay, ey, oy, aw, ew, ow, now what is the difference between ai, ei, oi, with an (i) and ay, ey, oy, with a y? as also between au, eu, ou, with an (u) and aw, ew, ow, with (w?)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: This: dipthongs made with (i and u) are pronounced short, those with (y and w) long: so that there are six perfect short, and six perfect dipthongs that are long.

p.hi: Have you any thing else to say of dipthongs?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Nothing at present.

p.hi: Having done then with dipthongs, a word or two of consonants, and first of them in general, what say you to it Michael, what say you?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What say I? what say Nicholas and Obadiah? for they are the two next-appointed speakers.

div.head: DIALOGUE VII. Nicholas, Obadiah. Of Consonants in general.

p.hi: OBadiah, how were we taught at first to finde out the natural sound of consonants?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: How? by the speech of some Stutterer, or stammerer, I think, who in labouring to express the first letter of a word, doubleth or trebleth it, before he can expressively tell us the word it self.

p.hi: Your instance in one or two words I pray.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Thus then, l l l lame, so b b b b big; now letters being first divised according to sounds, the stammerer (labouring to sound (l.) in lame (b) in big, as you see) taught us how to finde out the natural sound of (l) and (b) here, and so of the rest.

p.hi: How many consonants are there?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Nineteen, b c d f g h k l m n p q r s t w x y z.

p.hi: What is a consonant?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: A Consonant is a letter that must needs be sounded with a vowell.

p.hi: Cannot the consonants make a syllable without a vowel?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: They cannot, for without a vowel all the consonants put together, (onely (st), the note of silence▪ or so excepted) make not so much as one syllable; hence it is that (strn) spelleth nothing because there is no vowel.

p.hi: How are consonants divided?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Into 1 mutes which are nine, b c d f g k p q t, or 2 half-vowels, of which four, to wit, l m u r, are called liquids, these two, x z, double consonants.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: But stay (str) 9. mutes, 4. liquids 2. double consonants makes but 15. consonants, so that there are four of the 19. consonants wanting, to wit, (h s w and y, (when i t s a consonant)

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: True, these are (as you say) wanting, but as the letter s is a letter of its own power, and pronuntiation; that is, neither mute, nor liquid, nor double consonant, (as you shall hear by and by,) so we shall term the other three, to wit, h w y, to be like this (s) yet we shall call them consonants: but more shall be said of them hereafter.

p.hi: But why said you even now (y) the consonant?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Because both it and (w) also are (as hath been spoken before) sometimes vowels, sometimes consonants; but of them, as also of (h and s) more in some of the following Dialogues.

p.hi: So much of consonants in general, now what say you of mutes?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: What concerneth (mutes) let Peter and Robert say what they can of them, for 'tis theirs so to do.

div.head: DIALOGUE VIII. Peter, Robert. Of Mutes

p.hi: RObert what is a mute?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: A mute is a letter which hath the sound of the vowel (e) after it, and so forth.

p.hi: How many mutes are there?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Nine, b c d f g k p q t.

p.hi: But hath not the mute (f) the • ound of the vowel (e) before it?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: No.

p.hi: Why so?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: It answereth to (φ) fi the Greek letter, which hath the vowel sounding after it, now this rub (as we say) being removed, all the rest are so plain, and smooth, that none can stumble at them.

p.hi: What say you of the mute (q?)

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
That onely (u) with another vowel will
immediately follow it, hence it is that we say, qua, que, qui, quo, as quart, quern, quick, quetidian.

p.hi: But why not (quu?)

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Because no English word will have (quu) though some latine will, as loquuntur, &c.

p.hi: Now for half-vowels, what of them?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What is to be said of them, Samuel and Thomas are in readiness, to make plain to you in their Dialogue.

div.head: DIALOGUE IX. Samuel, Thomas. Of Half-vowels.

p.hi: THomas, what is an half-vowel?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: An half vowel is a letter which hath the sound of the vow • l (e) before it.

p.hi: How many half-vowels are there?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Seven, l m n r s x z▪

p.hi: What is the half-vowel (s) generally accounted?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Neither a mute, nor a liquid; but a letter of its own power and pronunciation.

p.hi: When is long (s) to be written? when short (s?)

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Long s is written in the beginning and middle of words; but short (s) when it is the last letter in the word.

p.hi: Your example.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: In this word (siste s the two former are long (ss) the last is short (s)

p.hi: But by your leave (Thomas) this that you say of short (s) as that it onely should be written in the end of a word, is not true.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: How prove you that?

p.hi: Thus, (to lees, to rais, to paus,) these three, to name no more, to wit, lees, rais, paus, have long (s) the last letter of the word therefore your rule faileth.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: For answer, There is no general Rule, but hath its exception, besides long (s) in these (and the like) words, is to difference them from others, else short (s) would take place.

p.hi: From what words doth long (s) difference them? can you shew us?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yes, that I can, mark then: These with long (s) are usual • y verbs, and are so written (I suppose) to difference them from plurals of N • unes; so then we write (to lees, to rais, to paus, &c.) as you see, lest they should be taken for these plurals: lees of wine, raies of the Sun, pawes of a beast.

p.hi: Can you name more words of this kind▪

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yea, that I can, but you must not expect them all to be verbs.

p.hi: Well, I will not.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
Mark then, to feel ones puls, puls at a rope.) the claus of a sentence, a birds claws, a duns, know not the duns from other colours,
physical dos, does in the park.) what els? ten els, 'tis fals, foul fals) sweet saus, blunt saws) good sows: fat sows) a tens in Gammer, to reckon by tens, or t • elves, but you must note one thing by the way.

p.hi: What is that?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: That these and others are often written with (e) after long (s), for instance to rouse Mr. Rous, and so of others.

p.hi: So words with long (s) difference words from those that end with (ce) and other letters.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: True, hence we say to neese, my neece: good pease, lasting peace; &c.

p.hi: Now you have pleased me to the full.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I am glad on't.

p.hi: Having done with half-vowels, come we to liquids.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Of liquids, hear Vincent and William, in the tenth Dialogue.

div.head: DIALOGUE X. Vincent, William. Of Liquids.

p.hi: WIlliam, you know that half-vowels are divided into liquids and double-consonants.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Yea, (Vin.) that I do, for the fourth Dialogue says as much.

p.hi: How many liquids are there?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Four, to wit, l m n r.

p.hi: What are liquids?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Liquids, are letters that do melt or lose their force after a mute in the same syllable; hence 'tis that in the word (blame l the liquid looseth its force coming after the mute b.)

p.hi: But why are these liquids call'd (sometimes) mutables?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Because of their various changes.

p.hi: How is that?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: By their several and manifold change of place, they make most variety of speech

p.hi: Tis like so, now a word or two of double-consonants, and then we have done with letters, to wit, the first thing (Orthography) treateth of.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Of them, hear Zachary, and Abel.

div.head: DIALOGUE XI. Zachary, Abel. Of Double consonants.

p.hi: ABel, how many double-consonants are there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Two, to wit, (x and z) and (i) also betwixt two vowels is reckoned a double-consonant among Latinists.

p.hi: Then belike (i) is sometimes a vowel, sometimes a consonant, and sometimes a double-consonant.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is so, as you may see in this word (jejunium,) the first (j) is a consonant, because it cometh before the vowel [e]: the second (i) is a double-consonant, because it cometh between two vowels, to wit, [e and u] the last (i) is a vowel, but no more of this, as belonging to the latine Orthography.

p.hi: To go on then, what is a double-consonant?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A double-consonant is a letter that hath the force of two letters.

p.hi: Hath (x and z) then the force of two letters?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea, x hath the force of (cs,) or as some of (gs) z of (ss.)

sp.speaker: Z.
sp.p: But stay, since there are 9 mutes, to wit, b c d f g k p q t, and 7 half-vowels, which subdivided again into four liquids, viz. l m n r, and two double-consonants (x and z) onely (s) being a letter of its own power, (as hath been said before) what is the reason there is no mention made of (h w y:)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: These indeed are not reckoned among mutes or half-vowels.

p.hi: Can you tell me why?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea, (w and y) are sometimes vowels, sometimes consonants, therefore (as others) so I also shall account them in a manner like (s) letters of their own power; and so to be neither mutes nor half-vowels.

p.hi: But what say you of (h?)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I say (h) is not properly a letter, but a note of aspiration or breathing, yet (for avoyding of multiplicity of rules) it shall be call'd a consonant, but like (s) too, of its own power and pronuntiation.

p.hi: Is (h) pronounced before Hebrew and Greek words?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is seldom pronounced before words, that are either in whole, or in part, borrowed from Hebrew. Therefore we say (Hierusalem) with four Syllables, though written with an (H): but before Greek words (H) is pronounced. So we say (Hierarchy) with four Syllables, pronouncing (H) in the first Syllable.

p.hi: Now you name the word Syllable, what is a Syllable? Which is the second thing Orthography treateth off.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Barnard and Clement shall tell you what a Syllable is, therefore I shall spare my labour.

div.head: DIALOGUE XII. Barnard. Clement. Of Syllables.

p.hi: CLement what is a Syllable?
A Syllable is the pronouncing of one letter or more with one breath
How are Syllables divided?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Syllables are divided into 1 proper, or 2 improper

p.hi: What call you an improper Syllable?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That I call an improper Syllable, which is made either 1. with a vowel alone, or 2 with a dipthong alone.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Shew us first how with a vowel alone.

p.hi: I will in this word (a-ble) a is an improper Syllable, may not the rest of the vowels, to wit, a. e. i. o. u. be improper Syllables as well as a?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yea, that they may. For in this sentence (a-gainst, e-ne-mies, i-deots, o-penly, u-nite,) the first Syllable of every word is a vowel alone, and therefore an improper Syllable.

p.hi: Now shew us how also with a dipththong alone?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thus, in this word (au-dience) au, is an improper Syllable.

p.hi: What is a proper Syllable?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: That which consisteth of one or more consonants taken together with a vowel or a dipthong. So the Syllables of this word (bounti-ful) all are proper Syllables because they have a consonant (at least) in each Syllable.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Having now spoken of letters and syllables, the two first things Orthography treatethof; come we now to words, which are made of Syllables, and first of them in general.

p.hi:
With all my heart Bernard; but Daniel
and his partner Ezechiah have undertaken that business: therefore attend them?

div.head: DIALOGUE XIII. Daniel. Ezechiah. Of words (more especially one-Syllable ones) in general.

p.hi: EZechiah, What things are principally to be learnt about words?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: These two things. 1 to spell truly any word of one Syllable. 2 to divide truly any word of many Syllables.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Are words then divided into words, 1 of one Syllable, and 2 of many Syllables?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: They are so.

p.hi: How many letters may be in a word of one Syllable?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Any number under nine.

p.hi: What example have you for it?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: This. (I do not know these rogues strange thoughts) in this sentence, the first word hath but one letter, the second two, the third three, and so forth.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By this then (I perceive) that an english word of one Syllable may have eight letters in it, though the latine one syllable word will have (I think) but six, as stirps.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: It is as you say, and these eight letters may be placed three ways.

p.hi: As how?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: First three consonants before three dipthongs, and three behind, as (straight,) or secondly two before, and four behinde, as (thoughts,) or lastly three before the vowel, and four behinde, as (strength.)

p.hi: Very good (friend) but hold a little. The first word of the sentence (I do not know, &c. (I) is a letter, and can a letter be a word?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: That it may, but an improper word

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: May a word then of one Syllable be divided into 1 proper, 2 improper?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Yes. But more of this in Ferdinand's and Gregory's dialogue.

div.head:
DIALOGUE XIIII. Ferdinand. Gregory. Of a word of one syllable
proper
or improper.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: GRegory, in the fore-going Dialogue an one-syllable word was divided into 1 improper, or 2 proper.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It was so.

p.hi: But may we divide a word so?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
In my opinion we may. So a word of
one Syllable, (made of an improper Syllable) may be said to be an improper word, and of a proper Syllable, to be a proper word.

p.hi: Make this a little plainer.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Thus. In this sentence, O sirs I always said God send us a King These three word (o I a) are words of one Syllable but improper ones.

p.hi: And in this sentence, Let the King live for ay, and ey whom he should aw, are not these three words, to wit, ay, ey, aw, because made onely of dipthongs, improper one-Syllable words also?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, doubtless, they are.

p.hi: What call you then a proper word of one Syllable?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p:
A word that hath one or more conson
• nts in it. So all the words in this sentence, (God bless King Charles) are proper words; because they have consonants in each of them.

p.hi: To pass by then an improper word of one Syllable, what have you to say of that, that is called proper?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I have something to say of, 1 the beginning. Something of 2 the end. Something of 3 the middle part of it.

p.hi: Begin now with the beginning of it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Content But that of the two next, lest they should be discontented.

div.head: DIALOGUE XV. Humphrey. John. Of the beginning (more especially) of a proper one-Syllable word with a Vowel.

p.hi: JOhn How may a proper one-syllable word begin?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Either 1 with a vowel, or 2 with a d • pthong, or 3 with a consonant.

p.hi: Your example for it.

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: This: in this short sentence of three words, (All s our King's) the first word begins with a vowel, the second with a dipththong, and the last with a Consonant.

p.hi: Indeed the word (all's) in your example begins with the vowel (a:) may also all the rest of the vowels begin words as well as a?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Que •• ionless they may.

p.hi: Your sentence (I pray) then with all the vowels.

sp.speaker: J
sp.p: This. An end, is of us.) in this sentence you see that each • ord begins with a vowel the first with (a,) the second with e, and so forth.

p.hi: So then (I perceive) that all the vowels may be placed before consonants, or may be the first letters in a word, but may all the vowels be placed before all the consonants?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: No.

p.hi: I confess, we may place all the vowels before the consonant (b,) for we can say ab, eb, ib, ob, ub. But you say all the consonants (though b doth here) will not admit of all the vowels before them.

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: I say so, for h) will not admit of (i or u) before it; nor q of i o u.

p.hi: Make this a little more plain to us.

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: I will thus then; we can say ah, eh, oh, with a, e, o, before h, but not ih, uh with i and u before it. So we say aquosity, Equity with a and e before (q) but not any word (as I can call to mind) will begin with i o. or u. before (q).

p.hi: Will all the rest of the consonants (h and q onely excepted,) admit of all the vowels before them in the beginning of a word?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: All will, none excepted.

p.hi: You said a little before, that all the vowels would begin words.

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: I did so.

p.hi: Yet, when w and y are vowels they will not begin words.

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: True. And the reason for (w) is, because it cannot be a vowel except another vowel go before it, therefore it cannot be the first letter in a word.

p.hi: What say you of y?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: That in English it is never the first letter of a word, no nor of words borrowed from Hebrew or Greek, as I remember.

p.hi: But some are wont to write (y) for (l) in the beginning of some words; as yron, ynough, and diverse others.

sp.speaker: J
sp.p: In so writing they do amiss; since that no word begins with a (y.) Therefore (Numps) you should write (iron, inough) with an (i,) not (y) at all.

p.hi: So much for a words beginning with a vowel, have you any thing to say of it's beginning with a dipththong?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Yes, that I have; but I shall leave that to Laurence and Matthew, lest they should mutter at us.

div.head: DIALOGUE XVI. Laurence. Matthew. Of a words beginning with any of the dipththongs.

p.hi: MAy the six perfect (called) short dipththongs, to wit, ai. ei. oi. au. eu. ou. begin a word?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes, that they may.

p.hi: May the six long ones also, to wit, ay. ey. oy. aw. ew, ow. do so too?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes, that they may.

p.hi: But are not the short dipththongs (as we call them) oftner used in the beginning of words then the others (which we call long) are?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That they are.

p.hi: And are not some of the imperfect dipthongs used oftner in the beginnings of words, then others are?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea, for (ea. oa) are more often used, as Earth. Eat. oar oats. • aten, &c. But ee seldom; as in this word (eel,) and few others. but (oo) so seldom, that I know (at present) no words, that begins with it.

p.hi: To pass then from a word's beginning with a howel, and also with a dipthong, come we to a word's beginning with a consonant.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Agreed. But Nathaniel and Oliver are resolved to see what they can say to it.

div.head: DIALOGUE XVII. Nathaniel. Oliver. Of a word beginning with consonants, and first with one consonant.

p.hi: OLiver; with how many consonants may a word of one, (yea and of many Syllables too) begin?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Either with one, two, or three at most.

p.hi: Can you give me an example?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yea these three words (King, bring, spring,) the first begins with one, the second with two, the last with three Consonants.

p.hi: What? Did the spring bring the King?

sp.speaker: O
sp.p: Nay, then, (I perceive) for one unparrallel'd rogue and grand tyrants sake of my name, you are leaving the matter in hand, and fall to jesting.

p.hi: Well then, though that (of the three (almost undone) kingdoms (hated) Villain, and his matchless Villan • es, be never to be forgotte • , whilst the world lasteth, yet because thou and many more of thy name (I suppose) be loyal and honest, I have done. To go on then. When a word begins with a Consonant, may it be with any of the Consonants?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yes, that it may with any, whatsoever it be.

p.hi: I confess, we can say ba. be. bi bo. bu. but will all the rest of the Consonants go before all the vowels, as (b) doth here?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: No, q will not go before any but (u), as you may see in the dialogue of Mutes. Neither will y, (when it is a Consonant) be placed before (i and u.) nor will (w) before (u), as hath been formerly proved by some of the speakers.

p.hi: Well, but I do not very well understand what you say, therefore pray make it (if you can) a little plainer to me.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: That I will: thus then, we can say ya. ye yo but not yi. nor yu. also wa. we. wi. wo. but not wu.

p.hi:
Now I understand you. Have you also
any thing to say concerning any other singl • Consonant's beginning a word?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yea, something concerning the Consonant c.

p.hi: What is it?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: This that (c) in the beginning of a word before a. o. u. if no other letter come between) is pronounced short like (K) but (c.) before (e and i) is sounded long like (s) hence 'tis that we pronounce ca. ce. ci co. cu. as if written Ka. se, si. ko▪ ku.

p.hi: But what if other letters, as (h. l. r.) come between c and e, or c and i?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Then this rule failes, hence we say (chest. clew crest) with h. l. r. between (c and e): and ship. clip. crip) with the same three again betwixt c and i.

p.hi: Have you any thing else to say of the Consonant c?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yes that (e) in words of one Syllable is placed before a. o. u. as cap. cope cup, &c. K before e. and i. as key. ken. kid. kiss.

p.hi: Doth this always hold true?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yes, except when we shorten some words or names; as Cis for Cisly, Kate, for Katherine.

p.hi: Having done with the Consonant c: what say you to the Consonant f?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: That in words borrowed from the Greek, ph. is used for it.

p.hi: Name some of those words

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Phantasy, Phenice, Philip, Physick, are four of them.

sp.speaker: N
sp.p: Next what have you to say of g?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: That (g) when (e or i) follow it, doth bring great hardness to learners.

p.hi: Why so?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Because g before e or i is sometimes sounded long, as (gender, giant) as if written with (ie. ji): sometimes short, as (get, give) so sounding like the Greek (γ) Gamma.

p.hi: Truly g before e and i sounded long (as you say) doth bring no small hardness; but (Nol) how shall we be sure when to write gi? when ji?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Because ji is rarely found in English, gi with g is to be written more useally.

p.hi:
But when shall we write g •
with (ie)?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: When the sound is long, as (gentle sounds) then write (ie) except onely in some words.

p.hi: What words?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: These, gest (or noble act) gem, gentility, generosity, gentile, generation, gender, genealogy, genitor, geometry, gesture, and few others.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: What say you of Gifford, with a g or Jifford with an J? Germine with a g or Jirmine with an J? and some other proper names; which some write with G some with J?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
I say that our english proper names are
usually written as pleaseth the painter (as we say), therefore we must be content to let them alone.

p.hi: Have you any thing else to say of g, or any other Single consonant, placed at the beginning of a word?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: At present, nothing.

p.hi: Let's proceed then to the beginning of words with two Consonants?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Let's do so; but Paul and Richard are pleased to do that for us, &c.

div.head: DIALOGUE. XVIII. Paul. Richard. Of the beginning of one-Syllable (as also of many-Syllable) words with two Consonants.

p.hi: RIchard, what if a word begin with two Consonants?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: The first of them must be a Mute, or the letter (s) or (w), which two we call letters of their own power.

p.hi: Then the four Liquids (l m. n r.) and the two double Consonants (x z) (belike) cannot be the first letter of a word, that begins with two Consonants.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: They cannot. Neither can the mute (q) because no letter will immediately follow it but (u) with another vowel, as hath been said before.

p.hi: Are there not other Consonants besides (q) that will require vowels immediately after them, and not Consonants, when they are the first letters of words?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea, all these eight; and these eight are all, to wit (h l. m n. r. x. y. z.) when any of these are the first letters of a word, the next letter must be a vowel or dipthong, hence 'tis that we say (h) hate, (l) lame (m) much, (n) night, (r) rash, (x) xenophon, (y) yes, z zealous. All which have vowels immediately after them as you see.

p.hi: But (m) will have (n) after it sometimes; therefore your rule failes. For we read this word (mnason.)

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That is a Greek word, and Grecians joyn Consonants in the beginning of words, that are not joyn'd so in the English.

p.hi: I am fully satisfied about (mn); which (indeed) is but rarely used. But what say you to R? Will not that sometimes have (h) after it?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: It will not have (h) after it.

p.hi: No? What say you to these words Rhythms, Rhume, and others?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: True. The letter (h) doth come after (R) in these words, but they are Greek ones too, now we (chiefly) are to speak of English-orthography.

p.hi:
Since we are now in a digression, to
digress a little farther, may we not give a guess at some other Greek-words by the letters as well as of this, that begins with (hh?)

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yes: usually these that begin with (th) though not all (thr. ph. phr. pn. ps. pt. ch. ct.) and some others; as also, these that have (y) in any (especially) of the first, or second syllables (though not all also) all these I say, now and then, nay often times are originally Greek words, so also (stl) begins the word (stlata), but cannot begin an English-word.

p.hi: But Richard; when you answered me about (th), why did you ad these words, though not all? are not all then that begin with (th) originally Greek?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: No. For most monosyllables are mere English: as thank thief, that, the, and so forth.

p.hi: But (friend) in your last instance you do not pronounce, thank, thief, like as you do that the.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I do not, therefore you must take notice, that some words with (th) are sounded sharp like (ϑ) theta the Greek (th): other flat, and little or nothing.

p.hi: Give (I pray) an example of some of them, that are sounded sharp.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I will: thank, thief, third, throat, and the like.

p.hi: Now also of some, that are flat.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
That, the, then, them, there, their, these,
thine, this, thou, thus, and others: ad to these words ending in (ther, thed, theth, thest, thing al •
flat: but I should rather speak of these, when I, or some other come to discourse of the endings of words.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: However; give me now some words that end in ther, thed &c.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Father, breathed, breatheth, farthest, farthing all being flat in the last sy • lable.

p.hi: Have yo • any more to say of any two consonants, that begin words?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea, something of (ch) which hath two several forces belonging to it.

p.hi: Pray, what are they? Name them.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I will; one belongs to English words, the other to Hebrew or Greek words, or english ones borrowed from them.

p.hi: Your instance now then for it's force in English words.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Change, chest, chip, chop, choose, and the like.

p.hi: Now also the force of (ch) in Hebrew or Greek, or English words, borrowed from them.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: These, chaos, cherith, chios, choos, chusa, choler, and others: where (ch) is pronounced like (k), as if written (Kaos, &c.

p.hi: What else have you of (ch)?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
This that (ch) in the names of 1 men, 2 women, 3 places throughout the old and new
Testament is pronounced alwaies like (K); as also in borrowed words from Hebrew and Greek, as was said before.

p.hi: But are there not words, that cross this rule?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea, some few; onely exempted by custom, as (cherubim) and Rachel, (which some will pronounce Rahel), these in the old, Tychicus in the new Testament, and so forth, ad to these Architect, and all words beginning with (arch), (arch-angel onely excepted.)

p.hi: Zh begins a word sometimes, yet is no Greek word.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Perchance (zh) doth so in some forrraign languages, but not in English.

p.hi: To digress no longer, may not (a double ll) and the like, begin a word in English?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: No consonant doubled will begin a word in English, but in Welch they may, and do sometimes, so they write (llan) in Welch; and the like.

p.hi: Now then to return again to our English-orthography, will the rest of the Consonants (but these eight you named before) have either consonants or vowels after them, when they begin a word?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea, hence these ten to wit (b. c. d. f. g. k. p. s t. w.) if they begin a word, may have a vowel, or a consonant follow them.

p.hi: One example for all.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: This▪ (to instance in (b) we may say black with a consonant (l) or back with the vowel (a) after (b) as you see: and this holds true in the other nine to wit (c d, &c.

p.hi: Yet before we come to discourse of a words beginning with three consonants, (for that is the next business) a word or two more of what we are about, to wit, the beginning of them with two consonants.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What you please, Paul.

p.hi: What consonants (in the beginning of a word) will onely follow (b)? what (c?) and so of the rest of the afore-named ten: for a word beginning with two consonants, (as you said even now) must begin, (if your rule be true) with one of these ten, viz. (b, c, d, f, g, k, p, s, t, w.)

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: To answer briefly, no Consonants but (l) and (r) will follow (b) in the beginning of a word.

p.hi: Pray shew us how?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Why, (bca, bda, bfa.) and so down along the alphabet, all spell nothing, until you come to (l): then we say bla, ble, bli, blo, blu, as blast, bless, &c and so with (r) bra, bre, &c. as bran, bread, &c.

p.hi: But will no more Consonants follow (b) but onely (l and r?)

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: No more will follow (b) but onely those two.

p.hi: Say you so? Why (d) will follow (b) as bdelium.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: One swallow (as we say) maketh no Summer: besides that is no Engl sh word; and it's a so sounded without (b) as if it were written delium.

p.hi: What will follow (c)?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Onely these three, (h. l. r.) hence we can say (running through the vowels) cha, che, chi, cho, chu, chap, cheap, chip, chop, chub, so cla, cle, &c. clad, clean, &c. So also, cra, cre, cri, &c. As crane, crest, cringe, &c.

p.hi: To go on, what consonants will follow (d?)

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Onely (r w) as drag, dwell.

p.hi: What f?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: (L and r) Flesh, frost.

p.hi: What g?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: H (but of it a few,) l. n. r. as ghost ghuest, glase, gnat, grace.

p.hi: What K?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Onely (n) as know.

p.hi: What p?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: In English words, (c. l.) as plot, pride, but in Greekish ones, (h. n. s t)

p.hi: What followes s?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: A jolly company, to wit, (c, h, k, l, m, n, p, q, t, w) all these, (if no more) as scand, shame, &c.

p.hi: What followes t?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: (H. r. w.) as that, trot, twist.

p.hi: Lastly, (for now I am come to the last of the ten Consonants, that will begin a a word of, or with two Consonants,) what will follow w?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: (h. r.) as what, wrath, and so I have done with a words beginning with two Consonants.

p.hi: Truly you have done very well (I think,) now let's go on to the words beginning with three Consonants.

sp.speaker: R
sp.p: Agreed, but what will Stephen and Timothy say; if they should be deprived of the next, which is theirs.

div.head: DIALOGUE XIX. Stephen. Timothy. Of an one, or many syllable words, beginning with three Consonants.

p.hi: TImothy, what say you, if a word begin with three Consonants?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I say, that the first of the three Consonants must be, either, c. p. s, or t, which are four of the aforenamed ten Consonants.

p.hi: Your Example.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Christ, with c. phrase, with p. strive, with s thrust, with t.

p.hi: But what two Consonants will follow c?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I suppose onely (hr) as christian.

p.hi: What two will follow p?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Hl. or hr. as phlebotomy phrase,

p.hi: What will s?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: These: ch, cl, cr, hr, ph, pl, pr, tr, if no more; as, sch, scl, scr, shr, sph, spl, spr, str, hence we say or write School, Sclander, scribe, &c.

p.hi: What will follow t, which is the last of the four, which will begin a word with three Consonants?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Hr, as thrust: hw, as thwart.

p.hi: But will not other Consonants have two Consonants after them in the beginning of a word, besides these four c. p s t?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Others will not, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yet, by your favour, there are some words that will begin with four Consonants, as phthoe phthisis, &c. Therefore the seventeenth dialogue (that says, that a word begins but with three at most) is not true.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: For answer, these have four Consonants, but they are Greek words, therefore do not at all cross our rule, no, nor our intention neither.

p.hi: Having done then with the beginning of an (especially) one-syllable word, which was either with a vowel, or with a dipthong, or with one, or two, or three Consonants at most; come we now to the ending of such words.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Be it as you say, but Valentine and Abraham's turnes are next to be served, and see, see, here they be.

div.head: DIALOGUE XX. Valentine. Abraham. Of a word's ending first with a vowel.

p.hi: ABraham how doth a word end?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Almost alike as it begins.

p.hi: How is that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Either with a vowel, or with a dipththong, or with one, or two, or three, or four consonants at most.

p.hi: What is your example?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This, (to say an oath brings strength:) the first word in this sentence ends with a vowel, the second with a dipthong, the four last with consonants: the first with one, the second with two, the third with three; and the last with four consonants▪

p.hi: Let us then in the first place speak something of a word's ending with a vowel, and first of all, what say you to the vowel (a? will any word end in (a?)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Though in other languages, as Italian, Spanish, French, the three daughters of the Latine) and in some others; very many words do end in (a,) yet (setting aside some Scripture-names
of persons, as Rebecca; of places, as Cana, Beersheba, and the like) it is not so in English: for in that tongue few will do so.

p.hi: Pray name some of those few, that will end in (a)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: These herbs (though not properly English words) Angelica, Galanga, &c. end in (a,) so also fa la. notes of musick. adde to these ha. ha. he) the interjection (as Scholars call it) of laughter), these and few others end in (a).

p.hi: I see then, there are but few that end in (a) but will many end in (e)?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: (Setting aside some Scripture-names as Phebe, Cloe, and so forth, onely (he) to wit, the last of ha ha he, and (the) few else will end in e.

p.hi: What say you to, he, she, me, we, ye, be, se, and others, are not all these ending in e?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea, we do often write them so, (I confess,) but it is (as I may so say) through custom against rule, for all these should be written with the imperfect dipthong (ee), and not with single (e): hence is it, that we distinguish (thee) from (the), saying, I tell thee the king is merciful.

p.hi: One thing by the way, many words that end with a vowel, or dipthong, or consonant, have also an e after them.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
They have so, but you shall have the
reasons of it at full, as they fall into our discourse, and when we come to speak more largely of the vowel e, at the end of a word.

p.hi: To proceed, do words end in i, o, or u?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea, but usually those that end in i, o, or u, have e after them, hence we say crie, see, true, &c.

p.hi: What's the reason?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I suppose this may be some small reason: because words in latine end in (i, o, u▪) without e after them; therefore in English we ad e for distinction-sake of those two languages.

p.hi: Well be it so as you say, but to return to the vowel (i), do not you finde that words do end sometimes with (ie) or (y)? Sometimes with (y) onely?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes that I do.

p.hi: Pray name some of them, that end onely with (y)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: These, my, by, thy, why,) are (through custom) onely written with y.

p.hi: Name also some that are written either with (ie or y.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: These, die, tie, crie with ie; or dy, ty, cry with y.

p.hi: But you (perchance) can tell us when to use ie when y?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If you will follow my direction, write (ie) at the end of a Noune; as a lie, a crie, and y at the end of a Verb: as to ly, to cry, &c.

p.hi:
This that you say (indeed,) is something,
but why should we write (ie) after nounes rather then after verbs? and e contra?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I'le tell you, in so doing, by adding (s) to the noune, you may handsomly make the plural, thus a lie singular, by adding s is made lies: so also by adding (ing) to y in the verbs (to ly, to cry, &c. these participles (lying, crying, are more hansomely made also.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: But may we not write y befo • e other endings, as (ed. eth. est. er, &c. as well as before ing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, hence we may say or write, (sayed, sayeth, sayest, sayer, but this last with er, because it is a Noun, we may write with (ie too, as saier, crier, &c. if we please.

p.hi: May all words be written with y in stead of ie except substantives or nouns as you call them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, all in mine opinion, hence we write very, heady, happy, &c which is far better then to write (verie, headie, happie, &c.

p.hi: What more have you now to say of the vowel (o?)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Very little, onely thus much; that sometimes single o is put for (oo) doubled: as do for dooe &c. also that some write (so, lo, &c. without e sometimes, and sometimes with it: especially the toe of the foot, left we should mistake it for to, as, To pray God to bless the King.

p.hi: What now of the vowel u?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That u also is indifferently written by some, either with, or without (e), as tru, or true, argu, or argue, especially if it be a consonant v as receiv. leav.

p.hi: Having done with a words ending with the vowels, come we to its ending with Dipthongs, and first with perfect dipthongs, which are either short, as, ai. ei oi. au. eu. ou. or long, as, ay. ey. oy. aw. ew. ow. will all these dipthongs end words?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, but none more fit to handle that, then Bennet and Christopher.

div.head:
DIALOGUE XXI. Bennet. Christopher. Of a words ending with perfect
short
or long dipthongs.

p.hi: CHristopher will perfect short dipthongs end words?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, but very few words, besides you must take notice—

p.hi: Of what I pray?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
That when (ai. ei. oi.) end words. 1 either e follows, as (staie. preie. boie: or 2 that most commonly they are turned into long dipthongs
to wit, ay. ey. oy: as stay, pray▪ boy.

p.hi: What say you of au, eu, ou?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I say they also may end some words, yet usually the three long dipthongs are used for them two, hence we write for gnau, with au the short dipthong, (gnaw) with aw the long dipthong, but the word (thou) is excepted.

p.hi: Can you give us some directions when to write (ai, ei, oi, with i? when ay, ey, oy, with y? So also when au, eu, ou, with (u?) When aw, ew, ow, with w)?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Though I dare not put it down for absolutely infallible, yet take this for a general direction.

p.hi: What is it?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: This: that usually the dipthongs with (i and u,) are written in the beginning of words, and those with (y and w) in the ending of words, especially if no consonant follow.

p.hi: Make this plain by some instance.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Thus, (aid, either, oile) you see begin with diphthongs, made with (i) day, valley, boy, those three end with dipthongs made with y, this that hath been said holds true also in the other six diphthongs, made with u and w.

p.hi: But what mean you by saying if no consonant follow, will dipthongs made with y and w be more used in the end of words when there is no consonant after them?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Yes, and if a consonant follow, then (i
and u) are oftner used, hence we say law, low, no consonant following, but laud, loud, the consonant d following as you see, though this also holdeth not always, nor in all too without exception.

p.hi: But stay, before I take leave of these dipthongs, and come to a word's ending with the other, (called imperfect dipthongs) with your good leave, a word or two more of y and w as they make dipthongs.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What you please Bennet.

p.hi: May we write e after y in the end of a word? As thus, staye?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No verily, that is needless.

p.hi: May we after w?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No neither (although for distinguishing some words (in my small judgement) one may put e after w sometimes, as when we say (he cannot bowe the bow, bowe with e would the better be known from bow without e, but custom oft prevails against Rule, yea, and against reason too sometimes.

p.hi: But hear you me, y as it makes the dipthong ay, may it be used both in nounes and verbs? As (a stay) which is the noun, (to stay) which is the verb?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Yes, it may, and that constantly too, yea, and in nouns both singularly and plurally, so we may write a stay, a day in the Singular, and stays, days in the plural number, nay in this
word which I named last, to wit, nay, and in any other we may use ay, as gay, may, lay, &c.

p.hi: But in substantives or nouns you say we should always write ie, (those ending in ay here onely excepted.)

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, except (l and e) or (n and e) go before as (valley, alley, journey, Atturney, and by adding s their plurals valleys, alleys, journeys, Atturneys.

p.hi: Now you have pretty well contented me, and somewhat satisfied me about perfect both short and long dipthongs, what say you now to the four imperfect dipthongs.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: I say, that some of them (if not all) will end words, but hearken to the two next that follow.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXII. Dennis. Edward. Of a words ending with imperfect dipthongs.

p.hi: EDward what say you to the four imperfect dipthongs? and first of ea.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I say that ea may end a word, without having an e after it, as yea, plea, sea, and so forth.

p.hi: What say you of ee?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I say that it also endeth many words, as as Hee, thee, see, tree, glee, &c.

p.hi: Concerning oa what of it?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: That very few (if any) will end with it (for ought I know.)

p.hi: What of oo?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: That not many will end with that too, but the word I last named, to wit, (too) without an e, and shooe dooe with an e (though we write now (do) as being better, these I say are with oo, and perchance some few others.

p.hi: Having done with vowels, perfect dipthongs, both short and long, as also with imperfect dipthongs their ending words; come we now to the ending of a word with a consonant.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: With all my heart, but Frederick and Gervase perchance will fret at it, if they should have a put-by.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXIII. Frederick. Gervase. Of a words ending with consonants, and first with one Consonant.

p.hi: WIth how many Consonants may a proper one-syllable or many-syllable word end?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: With one, or two, or three, or four consonants, and no more.

p.hi: Well; but may any of the Consonants end a word?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yes, any may end an English word except e, (having no e after it.) and q, to which we may ad (y and w) when they are Consonants.

p.hi: But (Isaac,) and other Scripture-names end in c?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: True, but you must note that these are not English-names.

p.hi: Why may not c end a word?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because though c and k are of like force, yet since c ends latine-words as lac, nec, sic, &c. and k english ones, as lack, neck, sick & therefore we use c in the latine, and k onely in the English, which when it is long hath e after it, as lake, bake▪ when short, no e as lack, back, &c.

p.hi: But hold, in your example you spell the english-word lack with ck why might not it be spell'd with c alone or k alone, since c, and k you say are of like force?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Why?
•
cannot (as I have said before) because it ends words in latine, and although k alone might do it, yet custom will not admit of k without c before it except—

p.hi: Except what?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Except 1 After oo or any other dipthong as cook bleak, &c. which have no c before them as you see. Or 2 when e at the end of k draweth the word long, as lake, blake, bake,
where there is also no (c) before (k),

p.hi: But now we talk of (ck) what is the reason that Rhetorick, relick, and others are written with (ck) and sometimes with (que) as Rh • torique, relique?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Truly both ways cannot be right, therefore to know how to write such words right, you must observe the words from whence those, and such-like words are derived.

p.hi: Shew us then (I pray) from what words these two afore-named are derived.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Rhetorick comes from Rhetorica, which being written with (c) therefore (c) is best in that word, relique comes from reliquus, which being with (que,) therefore (que) is best here also: ad to this last, the word traffique coming from the French too?

p.hi: Having done with (c) that end's no english-word, come we to (q) which (as you say,) ends no word also, but why will it not?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because either in the beginning or ending of a word, this (q) hath (u,) immediately after it: the word relique which we spake of even now, makes true what I say for the ending; and what hath been formerly spoken of (q,) in the dialogue of Consonants, makes it no less true also for it's beginning.

p.hi:
I am very well pleased with what you have said concerning the Consonants (c and q,) but why cannot (y and w,) when they are
Consonants, be the last letters of a word?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Because when they are Consonants, they must have a vowel after them, and if so, they cannot be the last letters in a word, as is most apparent.

p.hi: Well then c, q, y, w, excepted, I hope all the rest may be last, and end words.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That they may, onely the letter (e) cometh after some of them sometimes.

p.hi: Truly this letter (e) is a busy letter in the end of words, for it comes after some vowels, some dipthongs, some consonants; but hear me, will all the Consonants at the end of words, admit of (e) after them?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: No, onely some will as (k) when a vowel goeth immediately before it, as bake, like, and the like.

p.hi: Which will not?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: (x and z,) when they are the last letters in words, will not have (e) after them at ax, buz.

p.hi: Will all the rest have (e) sometimes after them, sometimes not?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

p.hi: When will they not have (e) after them?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: When the word is to be pronounced short, as lad, cap, fat, dam, and the like.

p.hi: Now again, when will they have it after them?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: When the word is to be drawn long as lade, cape, fate, dame, and the like.

p.hi: But what? Doth (e) draw the word long?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It doth, for to draw the word long, is one of its uses.

p.hi:
Now I think on't 'twas formerly promised, that we should know the reasons why (e •
was placed so at the end of words, or •• iefly all that might be known of (e) when we came to speak more largely of (e.)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: ' • is very true.

p.hi: Pray let this be the place then.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It shall, but why are you so earnest to have me tell you what I know of (e?)

p.hi: That I may the better understand what hath been spoken already of this letter, as also of what may be spoken of it hereafter.

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Well then, for your satisfaction take notice in the first place, that (e) (though seldom sounded at the end of words,) hath several uses, when it is placed at the end of them.

p.hi: But before you proceed to the uses, tell us what words will sound (e) at the end of them.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
1 At the end of these proper names, Jesse (Davids father) Penelophe, Phebe, and other. 2 after bl, cl, dl, &c. (e) in mine opinion (under correction,) say others what they please, maketh them to be syllables: so that (stable, shacle, ladle, &c. and others of this kind
are all words of two Syllables.

p.hi: What if these particles (ed, eth, est, ing,) be added to these kind of words, as also to some words ending in (er?)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: They are still but words of two syllables, hence we say or write stabling, entred, wondring, ordring, tendreth, all derived from, stable, enter, wonder, order, tender, and so forth.

p.hi: So then, to proceed to your uses; how many are there?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Principally two.

p.hi: Which be they?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: 1 First, it draweth the syllable long, as you have heard before. 2 Second, it changeth the sound of some letters.

p.hi: What letters?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: These three, to wit (u, c, g) so in (sau) which is with (u) the vowel, by putting (e) to it, it is (save) (u) the vowel, being changed into (v) the Consonant: may, and the sence of the word is changed also, hence we say, I will saue the sau, which we did saw with.

p.hi: Now for (c) what of it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Since (c) is like (k) suppose English words (though) (as you know) none will end so,) yet suppose them for this once to end with (c), and then thus (lic) ad (e) to it, 'tis lice, (lac,) lace.

p.hi: (g) also (which is the last of the three,) how doth (e) change it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It changeth (hug) by adding (e) to it, into huge, and stag into stage: both these words with (e) at the end being dravvn long, but if the syllable be short, then (d) comes before (g) vvithout (e) as badg, lodg, ridg, before (a, e, i,) (or as some vvill vvith (e,) and before (o, u,) as lodge, judge vvith (e) also.

p.hi: Having done with (e) (for present,) as also with the ending of a word with one consonant; come we to the ending of it with two.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Be it so, but Hugh, and his companion Joseph vvill jear us, if vve give them a regardless pass by therefore hearken to them

div.head: DIALOGUE XXIIII. Hugh. Joseph. Of a vvord's ending vvith two consonants.

p.hi: JOseph may a word end with any two consonants?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: A vvord cannot end vvith (e or q) therefort it cannot end, vvith any tvvo consonants.

p.hi: May any two consonants that will begin a word, end a word also?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: No, (sc, dw,) and other tvvo consonants begin vvords, yet vvill not end them.

p.hi:
In some one or other of the former dialogues, we are told that no liquid before a mute will begin a word of two consonants,
but cannot some liquids before mutes end words?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Yes, very often for instance (ld, bold, lf, self, lk, stalk, these three vvords do make good vvhat I say.

p.hi: But why say you very often?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: I say so, and that vvith good reason: for as the mute very often in the beginning of words of tvvo consonants, is placed before the liquid, so in the ending of vvords, the liquid (as if it vvould quit scores) very often comes before the mute.

p.hi: May two liquids (though they will not begin) end a word?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: That they may, so (lm as balm, rm as charm, rn as barn,) these three (to name no more,) ending vvith tvvo liquids, prove the truth of vvhat I say.

p.hi: Once more, you have told me that all two consonants, that begin words, will not end words, also that some (though not all) liquids before mutes, or before themselves, may (though not begin) yet end words: in brief Io) will any two consonants, that will not begin, (for all that) end words?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p:
Yea, some vvill do so, for instance (bs, ft, dg,) and the like, albeit they vvill not begin vvords (for bsa, fta, dga) spell nothing, yet these vvill end vvords, vvitness these three to vvit (crabs: vvith bs. shaft vvith ft, badg vvith dg,
all ending so as you see.

p.hi: But tell me one thing

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: What is that?

p.hi: May (e) follow words that end with two consonants?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Indeed Hugh (e) followeth many of them; but this is done out of beauty rather then necessity, onely two h • ve a kind of necessity of having (e) after them

p.hi: Which a e these two?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: (l and g) for if either of these two be the latter of the two consonants, in the end of a word, (e) followeth very handsomly.

p.hi: Your instance first for (l)

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: This (bl, pl,) as able, people where (e) you see comes after (l)

p.hi: Your instance next for (g)

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Words ending in (lg, rg, dg,) as divulge, purge, judge, have e after them, so also some with [ng] as plunge but in words derived from them you may leave out [e] as plungeth, judgment, &c.

p.hi: Why said you some with [ng] may not all with it have e after them?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: No, for if you place [e] after sing, 'tis singe, as to singe a swine.

p.hi: May e fo • low a word that endeth in [ck]?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: No, for 'tis needless, as also to put [e] after words ending in st, th, rn, nd,] and the like.

p.hi:
Say you so? Do not we read haste, paste,
taste, breathe, and others with [e] at the end?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: I confess we do so, but these [and the like] have [e] onely [as 'tis said else-where] to distinguish them from other words, especially the verbs from the nouns.

p.hi: As how?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Thus, thou hast made haste, to toste a tost, thou wast to blame to waste, past making the paste, to bathe in the bath, to breathe short breath, to blinde the blind, to minde with the mind, to taste a tast, and others.

p.hi: Well, now I suppose you have done with words that end with two diverse Consonants.

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: I have.

p.hi: Yet tell me, may a word end with (ll, nn, rr,) or any other Consonants doubled?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Lancelot and Mark, the two next intend to tell you, therefore I shall be silent.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXV. Lancelot. Mark▪ Of a word's ending with a Consonant doubled.

p.hi: MArk may a word end with a Consonant doubled?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Truly, (according to the opinion of the learned) there is little or no need of a Consonant doubled, at least wise of some of them) at the end of words, and therefore they write not ladde, rodde, barre, catt, but lad, rod, bar, cat,
and their plurals, lads, rods, bars, cats, which is accounted the better of the two kinds of writing.

p.hi: But there are, that use (e) after a consonant doubled.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I confess there are such, yet there is no necessity of using (e) so, for the word may be written with a single Consonant without (e) as (war,) but when they use the Consonant doubled (e,) doth no hurt at the end then, as (warre, barre, &c.

p.hi: Now we talk of Consonants doubled, pray tell me what Consonants may be doubled? What not?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In short, (c. q.) cannot be doubled, because these cannot be the last letters, (as you have heard before) in the word, neither can (w and y) (when Consonants) be so too, for the like reason.

p.hi: May (k and t) be doubled?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: (K) cannot, and (t) if at all, but very seldom, and onely to distinguish some words as to bat, the bird called a Batt, but the cow will butt, and so forth, if you please.

p.hi: May what is said of (t) be spoken of some others?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

p.hi: Well then, of those that may be doubled, there must be an (e) after them; must there not?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes, onely double (tt) and ll) excepted, and off with double (ff) which comes at the ends of verbs as thus to cut off, knock off, &c.

p.hi: But why except you (ll?)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because (ll) at the end of a word never hath (e) after it, though some in writing take no notice of it.

p.hi: But you said in the beginning of the dialogue, that there was no need of doubling at least wise of some of them, are any to be doubled sometimes of necessity?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea, these two Anne, Emme: and some other proper names.

p.hi: Are there any else?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea, such as these, asse, masse, mosse, &c.

p.hi: But why are these doubled?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
If a childish conjecture may take place, lest being spell'd with single Consonants (which are onely used in Latine) they should be taken for latine words; to wit, for as which signifies apound weight, mas the male-kind mos a manner, &c. So (ll] more especially in words of one syllable is used, and single [l] in the latine, as mel or Hebrew as Daniel, hence we say fel with single l in latine, and fell with ll in English, so also sonnes the plural of son we write as you see, to difference it from sons which is sounded like [mons pons,] so a curre dog differs from cur the latine word, and curres the plural from curs, but these petty nicities are not observed by
very many, therefore let them pass.

p.hi: You say that (ll.) and some other consonants doubled have not (e?)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I say so, as the word full sheweth plainly to us.

p.hi: Well, but may they not be (though this be not I confess) the place for it) may they not I say be doubled in the middle of a word?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No, if a Consonant follow as you may see by this word ful-fil where the Syllable ful is with single (l).

p.hi: What if a vowel follow?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Then they must, as (ful filling) where the syllable (fill) hath (ll.)

p.hi: Once more what say you to masse, passe, and the like (which now of late are written without (e) also, as (mass, pass,) will such have (e) also besides the (ss) when a vowel doth follow?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No, therefore we write pass-ing, pass-eth, pass-ed, leaving out the (e) that is at the end of passe.

p.hi: So much for words ending with consonants doubled, now of words ending with three Consonants.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Of them, hear Nathan and Philip.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXVI. Nathan. Philip. Of a word's ending with three Consonants.

p.hi: SChool-fellow, what say you of word's ending with three Consonants?

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: First, I say they are not so many, as those that end with two Consonants are: put case I could reckon them all to you.

p.hi: May any of the four liquids, be either first, or second or last Consonant of words that end with three Consonants?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Any of the four may be the first, onely (l and n) the second, and none of them the last Consonant in these kind of words.

p.hi: May all the rest of the Consonants be the first of the three?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No, not all.

p.hi: Name those that cannot.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will (b, h, k, q, z,) these five cannot.

p.hi: All the rest then, but these five may?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea, shall I name them.

p.hi: No, that would take up too much time, but tell me what Consonants will be the last of the three that words end with?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Onely these five (d, h, k, s, t,) as I take it.

p.hi:
What will be the second Consonants?
or thus, what Consonants may be placed immediately before (d)?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Onely (h) as (hd.)

p.hi: What will go before (h?)

sp.speaker: P.
