sp.p: These four (c as ch, p, as ph: s as sh: t as th.)

p.hi: What will go before (k?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: (s) as sk: though (seldom or never) sk is found to be the two last of the three Consonants in English

p.hi: What goes before (s?)

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: These three, [k as ks, p as ps, t as ts:]

p.hi: Lastly what goeth before [t?] for that is the last of the afore-named five?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: These and perchance others, to wit, [h as ht: c as ct: p as pt: s as st: k as kt: l as lt: n as nt: r as rt:)

p.hi: Now I am satisfied about these Consonants, as what and how many may be the first or second or third consonant in words that end with three Consonants, but are not some of these to be used figuratively, that is when a vowel is left out in the midst?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea, all these (if not more) to wit, (lct, nct, rct, lpt, mpt, rpt, rnt, rld, sh'd, sh't, ckt, lkt, nkt, rkt,) these 14 I say, for the most part are so used, as help't for helped, crush't for crushed, bedeck't for bedecked, &c.

p.hi: Can you say any thing else of words that end with three Consonants?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yes, this; that those are plurals that have (s) for their last letter, and that some of these plurals may be words of many syllables; as these words patients, deservings, sayings, and the like, prove it to be true.

p.hi: But what say you of them, that end with (d, h, k, or s?)

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I say they are not usually plurals, but for the most part, nay, I had almost said altogether, they are words of one syllable.

p.hi: What more have you of words that end with three Consonants?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Onely this, that none of them will have the busy letter (e) (as we call it) after them.

p.hi: So much for a word's ending with three consonants, come we to those that end with four.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Roland and Simon will tell you what they have to say of such, though I hold my peace.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXVII. Roland. Simon. Of a word's ending with four Consonants.

p.hi: WHat say you to words that end with four Consonants?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
I say in the first place that words of four Consonants are fewest, being not so many by
far as those of three, or two, or one, are.

p.hi: May the four liquids (l, m, n, r,) be the first of the four Consonants?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea, that they may.

p.hi: What other Consonants may be the first of the four also?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Onely (g as I can call to mind.

p.hi: What may be the last of the four?

sp.speaker: S
sp.p: (h s or t.)

p.hi: What may be the two middlemost?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Why, (ft, gt, ht, mt, gs, ph,) these six and no more, for ought I know.

p.hi: To be short, can you reckon unto us all or at leastwise most of the endings of words with four Consonants?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: That I can: words with four Consonants either end with (though rarely) lfth, ngth, rmth, or else with ghes, ghth, mphs or lastly ngst.

p.hi: But may not a word end with five Consonants?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: It may, but this is done figuratively, to wit, when some vowel is cast away from between them, as thought'st brought'st.

p.hi: Pray what vowel is cast away in these two words?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: The vowel (e) for they should be written thus, thoughtest, broughtest, with (e) as you see

p.hi:
What more have you to say of words
ending with four Consonants?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: That the word (strength) as it begins with three Consonants (which are as many as can begin a word,) so also it ends with four, which are as many as can end a word.

p.hi: What else?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I say, (to bundle up all,) 1 that words ending with four Consonants, especially those that end with (s) are plurals. 2 that they are for the most part words of one syllable. 3 that none of them will have the busy-letter (e) after them also.

p.hi: In your last answer, you said that those that ended with the letter (s) were plurals, wil you here take an occasion to tell us something of plurals? Though this I confess be a kind of digression.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Though I will not, yet the two next shall take the occasion to tell you what of plurals shall satisfy and content you.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXVIII. Tobias. Alexander. Concerning words that are plurals:

p.hi: ALexander, what call you a plural?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
That that speaks but of one, as one whip, one dog, you know is a Singular: but that
that speaks of more then one, as whips, dogs, we call plurals.

p.hi: Very good, I see that the two plurals, you mention here, to wit, whips, dogs, both of them end with (s) having no (e) before the (s) as these plurals trades, spades, lakes, and the like have, now how shall one know when to write plurals without (e,) when with (e) before (s?)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How? Why by these directions.

p.hi: What directions?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: First, mark where there is no need of (e) in the end of a word in the singular number, there is no need of it in the plural also: as hat, hats, land, lands, &c.

p.hi: But is there not some exception?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea, when the singular endeth with 1 a vowel or dipththong, as fly, or 2 with (w.) as crow, then (e) must go before (s) in the plurals, as flies, crowes, &c.

p.hi: When there is need of (e) in the singular, there must be in the plural also, must there not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea, questionless, so trade, spade, lake, (the words that I used even now) their plurals are (trades, spades, lakes, with (e) before (s) as you see.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p:
You say right, but what if the singular end either, 1 with two Consonants, as (ld) fold, (nd) hand. or 2 with a Consonant doubled without (e) as bell with (ll) or 3 with a
Consonant doubled with (e) at the end, as sonne with (nne) pray how must (e) be placed in the plurals of such as these?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I answer, that the two first, to wit, fold, hand, (and the like) are made plurals by putting (s without e:) saying folds, hands, next that bell, (and the like) is by leaving out the last (l) as bell, bels, but in the word sonne, (and the like lest it should be taken for (sons) (as hath been said before) we keep in (e) and write (sonnes).

p.hi: I have observed here all along that your plurals, have no more syllables then the singulars, but is it so always?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, sometimes the plurals have more syllables then their singulars.

p.hi: When is that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When the singular ends in (ce, ch, ge, dg, se, or sh,) as grace, church, cage, ledg, case, dish, all singulars of one Syllable, have graces, churches, cages, ledges, cases, dishes, all plurals of two syllables.

p.hi: What else can you say of singulars and plurals?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This, that (f) in the singular is turned to (v) in the plural, as wife, wives; knife, knives, calf, calves, &c.

p.hi: But let me ask you one question more? Do all plurals end in (es?) for all hitherto have done so:

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No, these, lice, mice, men, oxen, teeth,
feet, kine, and others do not end in (es) as you see.

p.hi: I see so, but may not the same word be sometimes singular, and sometimes plural?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, yes, these two, to wit, sheep, mile, can witness it.

p.hi: As how?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thus, we can say one sheep, five sheep, one mile, ten mile, or miles.

p.hi: So much for plurals, let's now proceed to what follows, to wit, the middle part of the word, and first let's say something of the enclosed vowel.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You say well, but Basil and Geoffry must not lose their turns, therefore expect them.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXIX. Basil. Geoffrey. Of the middle-part of the word, and first of the Enclosed-vowel.

p.hi:
GEoffry; (though you spell your name Jeoffrey) in some of the afore-going dialogues, we have had the beginning of a word with a vowel or dipthong made plain to us; as also the end of a word with a vowel or diphthong: now let's have the vowel or dipthong in the middle-part of the word (out of
hand,) explain'd to us?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: You shall, and first here are words with all the vowels, set down Rhymingly for memory's sake.

p.hi: Let's hear them?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: (a) bat, cat, fat, mat, sprat.
(e) bell, cell, fell, hell, tell.
(i) bid, did, hid, lid, rid.
(o) block, crock, dock, lock, mock.
(u) bug, hug, lug, snug, tug.

p.hi: Well friend) I have heard your rhyming-words as you call them, and that with all the vowels: have you any thing else to say, to words enclosing vowels in the mid'st, before you come to such as enclose dipthongs in the midst?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, this I have to say, if one doubt of the enclosed vowel (as some do) I shall tell him how to help himself.

p.hi: Shew how

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Suppose one should doubt whether bud be to be written with (o) or (u,) let him run thorow the vowels, as thus, (bad, bed, bid, bod, bud) and he shall quickly finde which of the vowels it must be written with; as for example 'tis here with (u) as bud.

p.hi: Very good, have you any thing else to say of words enclosing vowels?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yes, of some words, of which I shall say something.

p.hi: Pray let's hear them.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: You shall, and they are these.
a call, fall, branch, panch, cram, to damn.

p.hi: e. debt, get.

sp.p: i. Kiln, chil, spilt, guilt of sin.

p.hi: o. gold, bold, com, som.
u. hutch, much.
Now what say to the two first (call, fall?)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I say, that these two, and all such like, are pronounced as if they were written thus (caul, faul, the vowel (a) sounding as the dipthong (au)

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: So then, that may be the reason why branch, panch, and the like, France, prance, and the like were anceintly, nay are now very often written by some with (au,) as braunch, fraunce, &c.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Truly I think so.

p.hi: But is not (a) comming before (lt or ld) in the end of words pronounced like (au?)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It is hence we pronounce shalt, scald, as if written shault scauld, nay more, whensoever the vowel (a) cometh before (lm, lf, lk) we pronounce it like (au) but the (l) then must be silent.

p.hi: What's your example?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: This, qualm, qualms, half, halves, (balk balks;) are pronounced quaum, quaums, hauf, hauves, bauk, bauks) as if they were so written.

p.hi: To go on, why put you an (n) to damn, and not to cram?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
To preserve the word's Etymology; for it
comes from—damno, which hath (n) in it as you see.

p.hi: So then; that may be the reason why autumn, coming from autumnus; hymn from hymnus; and diverse others, are so written; as also that sepulchre, lucre, lustre, and suchlike; have the letter (r) before the (e) because they come from Sepulchrum, lucrum, lustro.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I believe it.

p.hi: But why put you (b) in the word debt, and not in get?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: There are some letters put into words, yet not sounded, of which this is one; but of them more hereafter.

p.hi: Why ad you (n) to kiln, and yet not sound it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: To distinguish it from kill as to kill a man, so also (u) is found in the word guilt of sin: to difference it from gilt, as a gilt-cup.

p.hi: Hitherto I like your answers, pretty well, what say you to the words (gold, bold)?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I say, that anciently they (and the like) were wrote with the dipthong (ou) as thus, gould bould, but to write them so now, is (as I may so say) quite out of fashion.

p.hi: What say you to these words (com, som?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
I say indeed they are pronounced as if wrote with (u) for sometimes we do pronounce
(o) before (m) and n (like (u) I think also 'tis to difference them from other words.

p.hi: What words?

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: Com and som with (o) differ from cum and sum the latine words; and so also son of man with (o) from sun in the firmament with (u).

p.hi: Very good, but why write you hutch with a (t)?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Indeed when a dipthong goeth before (ch) as pouch, slouch, and the like; or when another Consonant cometh between the vowel, and (ch) as belch, melch, and the like, there is no need of (t), otherwise there is, as in hutch here.

p.hi: But this word much, which was your other word hath not (t), and yet that word hath neither a dipthong nor another Consonant betwixt the vowel and (ch)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: For answer, there are some few words (through custome) excepted, of which this is one.

p.hi: Can you name some of these excepted-words?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, rich, which, such, much, to which I shall ad touch, (though written with a dipthong) because 'tis pronounced (tuch)

p.hi: Having said somthing of the vowels enclosed, come we to the dipthongs enclosed so also; and first of the perfect dipthongs, to wit, (ai, ei, oi, au, eu, ou.)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Let Hannibal and Jeremy handle that matter.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXX. Hannibal, Jeremy. Of the six perfect dipthongs enclosed.

p.hi: HAve you any thing to say of the perfect dipthongs?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Yea, that I have.

p.hi: Tell us what it is?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p:
I will for your better satisfaction, beginning first with the three first, to wit, (ai, ei, oi) so
(ai) bait▪ p • ait, wait, straight.
(ei) a vein, to reigne.
(oi) boil, droil, moil, spoil, toil.

p.hi: Why in your instance of words in (ai) hath straight (gh) in it, and none of the rest so too?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Because (gh) doth distinguish that word from strait, which is opposed to crooked, so (to digress a little) (gh) in might differenceth it from widows mite, right from a rite, or ceremony, and the like.

p.hi: Well said, but to proceed; why hath reigne a (g) in it when the other word hath not?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: To distinguish it from rein of a bridle, without (g.)

p.hi: Why hath it (e) at the end, when the other hath not?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: To difference it from the noun: thus, to reigne, a reign to veine, a vein.

p.hi: What say you to those in (oi?)

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: That some men do write some of them with (oy) long sometimes; as loyn &c.

p.hi: So much of the three first; what now of the other three?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p:
Something of them too; thus.
au fault, vault.
eu. —
ou. hour, pour, flour.

p.hi: What say you to fault, vault?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: I say that these two are always pronounced as if written faut, vaut, (l) being silent

p.hi: But why do you give no example to (eu?)

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: The reason is, because (eu) short is often turned to (ew) long.

p.hi: It may be so, now tell us why the word hour hath an )h?)

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Because the latine of it is hora, or, if you will, to difference it from the pronoun (our.)

p.hi: Well, but (h) in that word is not sounded, are there other words that are not sounded?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p:
Yea, these; heir of land, honesty, honest,
honour, host, hostisse, humble, and others.

p.hi: What say you of pour, flour: the two last having (ou) enclosed in them?

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: I conceive they are so written to difference them from power and might, flower of the field

p.hi: I like well what you say; but because, these childishly-lisping conjectures may not please others; let's pass over the six long diphthongs; to wit, (ay, ey, oy, aw, ew, ow,) and come to the four imperfect ones.

sp.speaker: I
sp.p: Well, content, but Leonard and Maurice, will be mad if they do not do it; and that presently.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXI. Leonard. Maurice. Of the four imperfect dipthongs inclosed, to wit, (ea, ee, oa, oo.)

p.hi: MAurice; have you any thing to say of the four imperfect diphthongs?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yea, something, as thus.
(ea) reade, spreade, bead, bread.
(ee) bleed, feed, need, speed, reed,
(oa) choak, cloak, moat,
(oo) blood, flood, stood, good.

p.hi:
But why hath reade, spreade, (e) at the end, the other two not? Is it to difference
the verb from the noune?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No, 'tis here to distinguish the present tense I do reade, I do spreade, with (e) which is long; from the preter perfect I have read, I have spread, without (e) which is short.

p.hi: We have been formerly told, that a consonant comming after a diphthong, needeth not (e) after it: neither doth a Consonant doubled, for the most part, nor lastly two diverse Consonants.

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: Indeed, without it be to difference word, or so, they need not have (e) in the end of them, I think.

p.hi: I think so too, but shew us some that will admit of (e) at the end.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To braine; there's a diphthong in the words, and yet hath (e) in the end. To tappe; there's a Consonant doubled with (e) at the end. To taste; there's two diverse Consonants with (e) at the end also, and you must note, that there are many of these last that will have (e) after it.

p.hi: But why is (e) put at the end of such words?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: As formerly, so now again, I tell you; 'tis to difference or distinguish words from words, especially verbs from nouns.

p.hi: To say nothing of the words which you named with (ee;) what say you of (cloak, choak?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I say that (a) in the in-side of these words answereth (c) in the end of others: therefore such words as these need no (e) at the end of them.

p.hi: Shew us how it answer's (e.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: choak, cloak, with (a) is answerable to poke, soke, stroke, which have (e) at the end, and so need not (a) at all.

p.hi: What say you of moat?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That the letter (a) doth difference it from mote in the sun, which hath onely (e) at the end.

p.hi: What say you of the words, blood, flood?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Onely this, that some of these words are written sometimes with (ou), as bloud, floud, and some are not; as good, stood &c.

p.hi: But by the way, why do we write (a thy my,) before words that begin with Consonants, as (a) dog, (thy) cock (my) lamb, and (an, thine, mine) before words that begin with vowels, as an elbow, thine eye, mine arme?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: 'Tis so done to avoyd a gaping sound.

p.hi: Now I suppose you have done with dipthongs enclosed in words, (especially in those of one syllable▪) shall we now come to words of many syllables, and what concerns them more particularly?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I confess, 'tis high time to do so; unless we intend to tire-out the reader's patience, but let's hear what Nehemiah and his fellow-speaker,
(that are the next,) will say to it.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXII. Nehemiah. Philemon. A brief repetition of what hath been spoken in several dialogues.

p.hi: WHat is our business Philemon at this time?

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: To repeat (briefly) what hath been already spoken of (especially) one syllable words; and then to proceed to what, more particularly concerns many-syllables ones.

p.hi: To begin then, there hath been spoken something of letters, of which we make syllables.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: True; and of syllables, of which we make words.

p.hi: Right; and of words of one-syllable which are proper or impr • per.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Very well; and of proper words as how they began with a vowel, or dipthong, or Consonant.

p.hi: Good; and that those that began with a Consonant, began either with one, or two, or three Consonants at most.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: As also, how that all words end, either with a vowel, or dipthong, or consonant: and so either with one, or two, or three, or four Consonants at most.

p.hi: All this cannot be denyed, but what else?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Lastly, that the middle-part of the word, that is concerning the vowel or dipthong enclosed, hath been said somewhat to.

p.hi: Now let's come to words of many syllables.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: With a good will, but Roger and Titus, will take it ill at our hands, if we should balk them at this time.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXIII. Roger. Titus. Of many-syllable words in general.

p.hi: TItus; can you tell me how many syllables may be in a word of many syllables?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yes, that I can, as any number of letters under nine, may be in a word of one-sylable; so any number of syllables under nine may be in a word of many-syllables.

p.hi: What example have you for it?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: This▪ (ho nest, tra-vel lers, u-su-al-ly, re-li-gi-ous-ly, (not) ir-re-li-gi ous ly, (walk) ex-tra or di na ri-ly, (with) ir-re-pre-hen-si-bi-li-ty,) in this sentence, the (three words to wit, (not walk with) which are put in onely to make up the sense) excepted) the first word hath two syllables, the second three, and so forth

p.hi: Are not words of (eight) syllables very few?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yea, very few.

p.hi: Are not words of (seven) syllables more in number then those of (eight:)

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yea, and those of (six) then those of (seven; and so of the rest.

p.hi: Words of one syllable (I know) for the most part are english, but what are those of two, three, four syllables, and all the rest?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Some are English, some are borrowed from the French, or Greek, or Latine, or some other languages.

p.hi: Let's have a taste of them that are borrowed from French, Greek, or Latine.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Victor and Walter (though I be silent) shall satisfy your appetite in this thing.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXIIII. Victor. Walter. Of words of many syllables borrowed from the French, Greek, or Latine.

p.hi: WAlter, what words are borrowed from the French?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: These, (and the like,) accrew, adieu, assail, attainder, lege • -demain, yea, and most of our law-termes, but—

p.hi: But what?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: But you must note, that 1 some of these words are with difference made English; as accomplish in English, is accompler in the french, and 2 some are without difference, as legerdemain, accrew, adieu, (if I be not mistaken) are the same both in English and French.

p.hi: Let us also have some directions how to guess at words borrowed from the Greek; both by their beginnings and endings.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: You shall, and first for the beginnings of words, besides (chr. ps. pt,) and others, (that have been spoken of in the dialogue, of the beginning of an one-syllable word with two consonants) I say besides these; these also that begin with, (ana, caco, cata, dia, eu, cpi, hyper,) and the like, as Anagram, Cacophony, Catalogue, Dialogue, Euphony, Epilogue, Hyperbole, &c. are Greek words.

p.hi: Now how to guess at them by their endings.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Words ending in (ogue, arch, uch, isme,) and the like, as prologue, monarch, Eunuch, baptisme, &c. are also Greek, but this you must note by the way.

p.hi: What I pray?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: That these comming from Greece through Rome, are new stampt, and we also (when with us) coyne them after our fashion.

p.hi: Shew us how.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p:
Thus, in Greek 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is baptismus
in latine, baptisme in English.

p.hi: Well then, you have given us tastes now of words borrowed both from french, and Greek: let's have a taste also by the beginnings and endings of such that are derived from the latine.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: You shall. Thus then; words (though not all) that begin with (ab, ad, bene, circum, super, trans,) and the like, as abuse, adhere, benevolence, circumstance, superlative, transgress, &c. are from the latine: to which we may ad many, words also, that begin with (am, di, dis, re, se, cno)

p.hi: Now how to guess at them by their endings?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Most words ending in ence or ance, are in latine in entia and antia, as patience, patientia, temperance, temperantia, so most words in (ion) being verbals; derived (as Scholars know) from the latter supine, are in (io) in latine, to go through all the vowels; action, connexion, derision, extortion, percussion, &c actio, connexio, derisio, extortio, percussio, &c.

p.hi: What words else?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Words in (ty) are in (tas,) as charity, charitas, in (ous,) are in latine (vs or osus:) as pious, pius, religious, religiosus, so our in or:) as honour, honor, (ble) in bilis: as flexible, flexibilis, and many more; but here also you must note by the way,

p.hi: What I pray?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: That all these rules, are not so generally true, as to admit of no exceptions: for (to instance in one for all) these words (fashion, onion) end in (ion,) but the latine words are not fashio, onio, thus much each Abecedarian can tell you.

p.hi: I believe you, but can you give us more of these?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Yea, that I can; very many more, but (to avoyd tediousness) I shall referre you to Mr. Willis his vestibulum linguae latinae, or as he also call's it, his dictionary for children, where you may be satisfyed to the full.

p.hi: So much for guesses of words by the beginnings, and endings, borrowed from the latine, but one thing by the way, may not what was said formerly about the beginnings, and endings (chiefly) of one-syllable words, belong also to words of many syllables?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Yea, doubtless they may, onely words of many syllables, will not end with four consonants, (as I take it.)

p.hi: What else have you to say of many syllable words?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Many things, but there are others, that will be angry, if their turnes should not be served.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXV. Andrew. Barnaby. Of things in some sort more properly belonging to many-syllable words, and first of their beginnings.

p.hi: BArnaby, are there not somethings, that may be said of many-syllable words, that do not so properly belong to one-syllable ones?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes, that there are:

p.hi: Who will treat of them?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will, considering once again the beginnings, then the endings, and lastly the middle-syllables, of such words of many syllables.

p.hi: Do so then; beginning with the beginnings.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Content, Andrew.

p.hi: Now then, what say you in the first place?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I say, to know when to write (ce or se.) when (ei or si) is doubtful, but because most are written with (s) as seated, sealed, sidelong service, &c. therefore (for the most part) write (s) before (e and i) and not (c.)

p.hi: But are there none excepted words?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Yea, these, and perchance some few others:
celebrate, celestial, celerity, censor, censure, Centurian, ceasing, cement, center, ceremony, certain, certify, ceruse, these I say with (e) are excepted?

p.hi: What are excepted with (i) pray tell us also.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: These, cited, cistern, cider, Cinnamon, circle, circuit, cirren, city, citizen, and all words beginning with circum, as circumstance, circumvent, &c. also civit, civil, with (i) are also excepted, hence 'tis, because cited is written with (c,) therefore incited, citation, incitation, are written with (c) also.

p.hi: But I find some words beginning with (e or i) as enquire or inquire, now which is the best way to write such words as these?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: If the derivatives be written with (i) then write always (i); for that is best: if with (e) then (e) still.

p.hi: Shew how?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Thus, because we write inquisition, with (i) information with (i) also, therefore to write inquire, inform is best, and the like may be said of all others of like kind.

p.hi: What say you of a word that begins with a vowel, having but one consonant after it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I say the vowel is commonly spell'd alone, as a-postle, e-quity.

p.hi: But is there not exceptions?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes, words of one syllable as (one,) and compound words as (un-able) are excepted.

p.hi: Now since you mention compounds, simples, primitives, derivatives; pray tell me (for my better understanding of them) what they are?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Mark then. A primitive is the first word not derived of others.

p.hi: What is a derivative?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A derivative is a word drawn from the primitive; or thus, a primitive is the root, or fountain; derivatives, are the branches, or streams: the primitive, (if there be any) is, usually the verb; as to love all the rest of the family, (if I may so call them,) are the derivatives: so the noun 1 of the person, to wit, a a lover. 2 of the thing, to wit, love, also the participles, lov • ng, loved, the adverb, lovingly, and if any other, all are derivatives.

p.hi: What call you now a Compound?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A compound is either, 1 when two simple words are joyn'd together, as here • f, wherein, safegard, and the like, or 2 when prepositions are added to beginnings of words, as with (dis.) disjoyne, circum, &c.

p.hi: When particles unsignificant, as nesse, lesse, ly, &c. be added to the end of words, what then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
What then? Then we may call such
vvords a kinde of Compounds also.

p.hi: What call you a simple word?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That, that is not compounded, and indeed the parts of a compound word are simple words properly.

p.hi: I am now sufficiently informed, can you (to return to our plough again as we say,) tell us something of the endings of many syllable words?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: If I cannot, Edmund and Giles can; the two next.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXVI. Edmund. Giles. Of the endings of such like words.

p.hi: WHat have you to say of the endings which are more proper to many syllable words?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Something: As first that some of them end in (ie or ey,) as monie, journie, tansie, with (ie) or money, journey, tansey with (ey.)

p.hi: What else?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That words in (or and ors,) short, are differently written with (or and ors,) else with (our and ours:) as savor, savour, Savors, Savours, and these are commonly pronounced—

p.hi: How?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Like (ur and urz:) as if written savur, savurz.

p.hi: But are not monosyllables, (for, nor, dor) and some others, as (abhor,) excepted?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yes, that they are.

p.hi: What say you of words in [ous?]

sp.speaker: G
sp.p: That they, and their derivatives are commonly pronounced like [us,] so we say various▪ variously, as if written varius, variusly, &c.

p.hi: But are mono-syllables as [thus, truss] excepted?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, yea.

p.hi: What say you of words ending with [er and ers with e?]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I say that they are commonly pronounced l • ke [ur and urz] with [u:] as laver, lavers, like lavur, lavurz, &c.

p.hi: But such that have their accent on the last syllable, I hope are excepted.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yes, hence 'tis that averre, referre, deferre, and the like, are never sounded as if wrote with [ur.]

p.hi: What say you of words that end in [eth?]

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
We pronounce such as if written with [s,] and sometimes with [z] so bolteth, holdeth, are pronounced, as if written; bolts, holdz, so also leadeth, noteth, taketh, we commonly pronounce,
nay, and the learned write them; leads notes, takes.

p.hi: But are there not some, that will not be thus pronounced?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, such as have either (c. s. sh. ch. g. or x.) going before (eth:) all these remain as two syllables, so placeth, pleaseth, washeth, watcheth, wageth, waxeth, make good what I say, yet some there are that say, (though not very well) washes, watches, and so of the rest.

p.hi: Have you any thing else to say of these words endings?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, that words ending in (ance, ence, ince, once, unce, ancy, ency,) are most commonly written with (c.)

p.hi: What more?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That the vowel (a) hath usually (c not s) after it: as grace, space, place, except—

p.hi: What?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Except, 1 case, base, chase, and few others or 2 when (s) (coming between two vowels) is sounded like (z:) as amase, as if wrote amaze.

p.hi: You said even now, that words written with (ance or ence), were written with (c:) but by your favour, many words in (ence) are wrote with (s,) as to recompense, to fense, and the like.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
True, but these are verbs, and are so
written, to difference them from the xonnes, which we write with ence with a (c:) hence we say▪ to fense a fence: to recompense a recompence: to devise a device.

p.hi: And are there not other words, that are so differenced?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, as to practise, a practice, the first with (s,) the last with (c.)

p.hi: But there are some, that are not so differenced; for what, say you, to these? To excuse, an excuse, to abuse, an abuse,) to use an use, to rise a rise?)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: True, in these the noun is not differenced from the verb by (c,) yet they are by accent, for the verbs have their accent in the last syllable, the nouns in the first, as you may see.

p.hi: What say you of the one syllables words (use, rise?)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I say, that the verb is sounded in these vvords, as if wrote vvith (z): as to use; as if it vvere vvritten thus; (to vse, a vse,) to rize a rise.)

p.hi: Are there no more words of this kinde, thus differenced by accent?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yes. To convert, a convert,) to rebel, a rebel) to incense, the incense, here the nounes (vvhich are knovvn by having (a an or the) before them) these (I say) are lifted up in the first syllable, the verbs in the last.

p.hi: Again, there are some words, that are like these, that are sounded, and written alike; how shall we difference such?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Onely by their differing in signification; so (a well) differs from, (I am well,) and a bell-weather, from fair weather vvhich holds the same in others also, ad to these General of an army vvith great G, and general rule vvith a little g, and the like.

p.hi: But to draw to a conclusion of this Dialogue, there are some words (most of them not write alike, I confess) yet so nere in sound, that I know not (almost) how to difference them.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: These also are usually differenced by their signification: and if you vvill, you shall have here a little Catalogue vvorth your reading.

p.hi: Content.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But let the tvvo next repeat it, for I am vveary.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXVII. Isaac. Marmaduke. A Catalogue of vvords near in sound, differing in writing and signification.

p.hi: PLay-fellow, you are appointed to repeat the Catalogue.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am so, and my method shall be to give you a sentence in the several letters of the Alphabet.

p.hi: Pray then begin with the letter (a,) and so proceed to one of (b,) and so forth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I vvill do as you vvill have me, so that you vvill not be too strict an observer of the sense of these sentences, vvhich (for bringing in of these kind of vvords) must needs be lamish, frivolous, and faulty.

p.hi: Well then, I will not, proceed to your Catalogue, beginning with a sentence in the letter (a.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: At the (ascent) of (an) hill (Anne) and I, did (assent) to break (all,) the Shoe-makers (awle,) because he vvould (alter) the place vvhere the (Altar) stood.

p.hi: I like this sentence of (a) very well, now one of (b.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Mr. (Ball) (by) vvhose meanes I did (buy) a (barque,) (or little ship), had a dog that did (bark) and (baul) at the maid, that vvas vvont to (bolt] the door, and (boult the meal; lest the vvind [vvhich [blew] avvay the [blue] cloth] should offend her.

p.hi: Have you another of [b?]

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yea. Our man, vvhose name is (Brute) [bred] up vvith brovvn (bread,) being drunk vvith (beer) like a (brute) beast thought it
best to (bruit) it abroad, that we did (bore) the (boar's) ear, and did (bear the dead (Bear) on a (bier.)

p.hi: Proceed to (c?)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Mr. Cox that kept cocks, told one Cotes that sold coats, that for all he was a culler of apples of a good colour, and his Cousin: and (quoted) scripture as well as coated children: yet neither he nor the butcher that did call for the caul of the liver, should cozen him of his dogs coller, unless they would be willing to provoke him so to choler as to take counsel of the King's Council against them.

p.hi: Have you another of (c?)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes. The cruel Mr. whose cap was wrought with crewel, with his wicked crue, before the cock crew, gave consent to have a concent of musick, as also to chase the dear that were in the chace.

p.hi: Now one in the letter (d.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Mr. Deyer the dyer of cloth, my dear friend, that kept a fallow-deer, he (I say) never saw the Daulphin of France ride on a Dolphin-fish through the deep to the town of Diep.

p.hi: Your little one of (e) next.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: When Mr. Eaton went to Aeton colledge at Easter, his bread was eaten by his maid Esther

p.hi: Your sentence in the letter (f.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I would fain give Philip that went farther
then the further bank, a fillip on the brow, because he did like a foul fool go far for his fathers feather, and then run away with the great fowle, and after that did stick the sweet-smelling flower in the wheat flour, that lay on the floor, and then did feigne himself sick.

p.hi: Now one of (g.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I ever guest, that he that did fish with a gentil (or maggot,) and then did steal the gent • e-mans gilt cup, and through the guilt of sin, did afterwards gage it to him that did gauge vessels, I say, I guest that he could never be a welcome ghest, to the owner of it; who now doth grone because his corn is not well grown.

p.hi: Of (h) next.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Haply black Hugh, that will never change bue had happily an heir, here in this place, as I hear, who with his long hair did run after an hare or a hart in the hollow part of the hallowed ground, tell he had almost broke his heart, whom at last having caught, he did hy him home, to tell it to high and lovv, singing a hymn not heigh-ho, to the men in the hoy, and other higher persons; whom he durst not hire at all, to run (as I heard,) in that vvay hard vvay, vvhere his goos did hiss.

p.hi: Come we to (I) the vowel.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
(I) say he that did (incite) the man (in) the (Inne) to (ire) (to vvit anger,) and to be an (eyer) of us, so as to (ey) us vvith his (eye,)
had but small in-(sight either of (iles) in the churches, or of (isles) in the sea.

p.hi: Of (J) the consonant next.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: To do a (gest) (or vvorthy act) in jest, to jet up and dovvn vvith a jeat-stone: to pour juice of fruit on a joice, that bears up the boards, is the part rather of a foolish carpenter, that knovvs a jointer, (or tool to vvork with,) and not of a man, that can make his vvife a joynture, and may fish in the river Jorden, vvhere a jurden is throvvn sometimes.

p.hi: Now (k's) sentence.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I gave knok our boy many knocks, because he made the dogs kennel in the (chanel), of filthy water, and did hide the deer, vvhich he did kill, in the Kiln vvhere the bricks vvere burnt.

p.hi: L's next.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A Seller of (Latten) ladles nere learneth the (latine) tongue, and he that giveth his (leman) (or concubine) a (limon) or Orenge, vvill not sell the (lease) of his house, for a (leash) of hounds, or an horse-(licter,) for a (litter) of vvhelps.

p.hi: Have you another of (l)?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yes, he that is a (luster) after vvomen, shall never have the bright (lustre) of a good name, he may be a good (leaper) not a (leper) full of sores, yet one of a (lower) stature, may
have more of vvisdoms (lore) then he, if he be careless, let him take heed (lest) the (least) in the school of christianity, out-strip him in the (lesson) of goodness, and so God (lessen) his revvard.

p.hi: Shall we have one of (m?)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes, our man, vvho once gave a mite to shevv his might, did mete, vvith a yard the meat he did eat, his name being Martin, he did catch a bird called a marten vvhilst Maurice the other man, dancing the morrice (by reason of a mote in his eye) fell into the moat (or ditch,) of those meads vvhere the Medes, and Persians vvere.

p.hi: Let that of (N) be next.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yes, It shall. Though Mr. (Nye) that dvvels (nigh) or (near) this place, (nere) say (nay); yet a horse, that is so (naught,) that he is good for nought,) vvill seldom (neigh.)

p.hi: One now of (o.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The vvater man being an ower of debts, vvith his oar can never get gold ore: and the country-man that put's his ordure on one, of the lands in good order can tell us that every (hour) of our life so hastneth avvay, that vve ought not to spend aught thereof idly.

p.hi: One of (P.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Mr. Paul Pierse, the poor parson, (though a comely person or a prophet) must not count it
profit to wear the robe call'd a Pall, or to think that he hath power to pierce with a sword, or to pour-out of the palate of his mouth, when he lyeth on a pallet, words against the pastor of sheep in his pasture, where he doth pray, that the wolf may not prey upon them.

p.hi: (Q's) little one.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: She must needs be a quean, that is quite against the Queen, and yet thinketh to be quit.

p.hi: What is (R's?)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Every (wheel-wright) cannot (write) right a rite or ceremony, neither can good man Rice, though he take a rise, leap over the place where the rice was sowen, and where in the rain, the King that now doth reigne, did hold the rein of his horse's bridle, neer the great room, though not in the city of Rome.

sp.speaker: I.

p.hi: What is the sentence in (s?)

sp.p: This, Mr. Shute did shoot at a bird, and follow the suit in law, in his new sute, the same day that his man Sligh that sly fellow, did sue in law him that did sew the skin of the sowe, and sow corn, and at his answer, swear on a Shooe-sole, pawning his soul for some small summe of mony, as one did shew, or declare to us.

p.hi: Now there are but few of the letters left that must have their sentences.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You say true Isaac, but shall I go on to the rest?

p.hi:
Pray do, and say the sentence that belongeth
to (t) for that is the next letter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: We (two) (then,) (rather (than) you), were (too) blame to, hurt the man's (toe,) and to lay no f • ax or (tow) upon it.

p.hi: (v) also hath it's sentence, hath it not?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea, and there is a little Rhyme for it, which is;
That every thing might (vain) appear.
We have a (vein) for each day in the year. And you cannot fill a (vial,) and play on the (viol) at the same instant.

p.hi: (W's) I pray you.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If you ask whether I went any whither yesterday? I tell you that when I did wait upon my Mr. with a gold weight in mine hand, at the town of Wich, there were some that did see a witch covered with woad, and in a wad of straw to wear the man's shirt, that had a wey of chees, in the way as you go to the house of him that doth weigh gold.

p.hi: Now one of (y,) and I have done.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You must not hang your Basin and Ewr in the yew-tree, neither must ye that say yea, do the like. Now (in good sooth,) how like you the Catalogue?

p.hi: So well, that I think he is not well in his wits, that findes fault with it, (although you have brought the words ey, in the letter I, and write in that of R to explain others in those, and in some other letters.)

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am very glad to hear you say so.

p.hi: But stay Marmaduke, before this Catalogue's repetition, something was spoken both of the beginnings, and also of the endings of many-syllable words, was there not?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea, verily, there was.

p.hi: But nothing of the middle-syllables, as I can call to remembrance.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Nothing, indeed nothing.

p.hi: Shall we now go and say something of them?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Shall we go aside, and let the two next take their turns, that have undertaken it?

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXVIII. Ralph Sebastian. Of the middle-syllables of many-syllable words.

p.hi: BEd-fellow, what do you call middle-syllables?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I call all middle-syllables, except the first and last syllables in the longest word whatsoever.

p.hi: Give us an example.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: In this word (commemoration,) these four, to wit, (me-mo-ra-ti) are middle syllables in mine account

p.hi: Good, now what say you of middle syllables?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I say first; that some of them have (c) in them, some (s) some (t,) as capacity infusion, nation, the first with (c,) the second with (s,) the last with (t,) as you see.

p.hi: But how shall I know when to write (c,) when (s,) when (t?)

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: From the primitive word, as to instance in the three fore named, capacity comes from capax, capacis, with a (c) therefore write that with (c:) infusion comes from infusus with an (s) therefore write that with (s:) nation from natus, therefore write that also with (t.)

p.hi: Have you any thing else to say of middle syllables with a (c?)

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yes, that some of them have (ci) with a (c,) as suspicion, some (si) with an (s) at version, some (ti) with a (t) as redemption, some (xi) with an (x) as complexion.

p.hi: But how shall we know when to write all these?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: (ci and xi,) (with c and x,) are seldom, but (si with s,) more often used, as casion, cession, passion, rision, vision, &c.

p.hi: Is this all?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: No, you must observe too, that most of these words are verbals comming from the latter supine (as Grammarians can tell you,) and are made by changing (u) into (io) in latine, into (ion) in english, so from complexu cometh complex • o, complexion, and so of the rest.

p.hi: Now what say you of (ti?) Is it before a vowel pronounced always like (si with s?)

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: No.

p.hi: When is it not?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: 1 when (s) goeth immediately before (t) as question, or 2 when (x) as mixt on, 3 when the particles (est, ing, ed, eth) are added to the word ending in (ti,) as loft i-est, pitty ing, pitty-ed pitty-eth, 4 when it is the first syllable of a word as (ti-able.)

p.hi: What more of middle syllables?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: This, that be, ce, de, fe, ge, le, me, ne, pe, re, se, te, que,) these thirteen are not usually spelled by themselves in the middle of a word, if a vowel go before, hence 'tis sure-ty not sure-ty, pure-ly, not pu-re-ly, and so forth, besides all these too, (though this be not the right place for it,) are never the last syllables in the word, but must have other letters joyn'd with them, onely some proper names, as Phebe, Mamre, and the like, excep • ed.

p.hi: Your example.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Mark then, we say or spell, genu-ine, not genui ne, as-sure, not as-su-re, forti-tude, not forti tu-de, infi-nite, not in-fi-ni-te, &c.

p.hi: Hitherto what hath been spoken of the beginnings and endings, of many syllable words, and what you have now spoken of the middle syllables of words, is very good I confess, yet there remain two things worth observation.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: What are they?

p.hi: Why: the one is to know certainly, (at first sight) how many syllables there are in any word of many syllables, and the other is (when known once) how to divide them truly.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Indeed these are two things worthy to be known, but let the following speakers speak what they have to speak of them.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXIX. Theodore. Anthony. To know certainly (at first sight) how many syllables there are in any word of many Syllables.

p.hi: ANthony, can you shew how I, or any may have a certain knowledge of the number of Syllables in a word of many syllables?

sp.speaker: A:
sp.p: Yea, that I can.

p.hi: Let it appear then, I pray.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thus, mark how many vowels are in the word, just so many syllables the word is of.

p.hi: But by your good leave, these six words, to wit, (make, meat, maid, names, quilt, gualter,) seem to, nay do contradict your assertion.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Verily they do, therefore know, that there is hardly any general rule without some exceptions.

p.hi: Pray how many exceptions are there here?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Six, just so many as you have named exceptive words, nay each of your words makes a several exception.

p.hi: What is the first exception?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This, when (e) (not sounded) endeth a word, as for example, the first of your exceptive-words, to wit, (make) maketh good what I say.

p.hi: A second exception what is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When a vowel in a word is but little sounded, so (meat) another of your words hath (a) but little sounded in it.

p.hi: But are there not other vowels that are little sounded besides (a?)

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There are, and Consonants too, but more of such as these by and by.

p.hi: To go on, what is your third exception?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When there is a perfect dipthong in a word, as (ai) is in your word (maid.)

p.hi: What is your fourth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When the word ends in (es,) as your word (names) doth.

p.hi: But is not (es) spell'd by it self at the end of a word?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is spelled very seldom by it self; except the letters going before it make a perfect word, as (rich-es.)

p.hi: To go on then, the fifth what is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When the word begins with (q,) for then (u) with another vowel must follow of necessity, (as hath been said before,) and your word (quilt) can testify as much.

p.hi: What is the sixth or last exception?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When (g) begins a word sometimes, for that like (q) will have two vowels after it sometimes, witness Gualter) the last of yours.

p.hi: Me thinks, by what you have said, I certainly know now, how many syllables are in a word: but how shall I know how to divide them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nay, let Gilbert and Job, (the two next) tell you how to divide them.

div.head: DIALOGUE XL. Gilbert. Job. How to divide a many-syllable word, as first by considering the vowel or dipthong between two consonants.

p.hi: WHat if a vowel come between two consonants in a many syllable word, as in this word gra-ti-fy (i,) doth betwixt (t and f?)

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: It must be placed with, or put to the former consonant.

p.hi: Why so?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Because, the latter syllable cannot begin with a vowel, except the former syllable do end with a vowel. And by the way note—

p.hi: What?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: That every syllable in a long word must (if it can) begin with a consonant.

p.hi: What if a diphthong or two vowels (one of them little sounded,) come between two Consonants, as (oi) in the word em-broiderer doth between (r and d,) (ie) in the word mis chie-vous doth between, (h and v consonant,) must they also be put to the former consonants?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Yea, that they must.

p.hi: What if two vowels come together that will not make a diphthong (both fully sounded) how will you place them?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: The former must be placed in the former syllable, the latter in the latter syllable, as in this word vali • ant (i) is in the former, (a) is in the latter syllable, as you see.

p.hi: If two vowels come together, that will make diphthongs either perfect or imperfect, must they remain always diphthongs?

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Yea, I suppose they must, except in some proper names, as Shepharva-im, where the dipthong (ai) is divided, Caper-na-um, where the perfect dipthong (au,) also is divided, Gile ad, Be-ersheba, Jo athan, Bo-oz, where you see the four imperfect diphthongs (ea. ee. ea oe, divided also.

p.hi: Now I am satisfied about a vowel's or dipthongs coming between two Consonants; something I pray now of a Consonant's coming between two vowels

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Pray not me, pray the two next, to wit, Lewis and Martin.

div.head: DIALOGUE XLI. Lewis. Martin. Or secondly by considering the consonant, or consonants between two vowels.

p.hi: MArtin, what if one single Consonant be placed betwéen two vowels? As (m) the consonant is in the word a-ma-rous?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It must be put to the latter vowel, or syllable, (onely (x) as ox-en is excepted.)

p.hi: Why so?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because, the former syllable cannot end with a consonant, except the latter syllable begin with a consonant.

p.hi: What if two consonants that will begin a word, come between two vowels, as in brother (th) doth?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They must be placed with the latter vowel or Syllable.

p.hi: Why so?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Because, those that will begin a word,
must begin any syllable in a word.

p.hi: What if two consonants that will not begin a word, come between two vowels, as calum-ny, cen-ter?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They must be divided, the former going to the former, and the latter to the latter syllable, so these two words before mentioned do prove it, as also the word (bun-dle,) and the like.

p.hi: Why may not both of them be p •• ced with the former syllable?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because, the former syllable cannot end with a consonant, when the latter syllable doth not begin with a consonant.

p.hi: What if three consonants come betwixt two vowels?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If they be such that will begin a word, they must be placed with the latter syllable as (fru-strate) if not; they must be divided as (emblem.)

p.hi: What if four consonants or more come betwixt two vowels, as con-strain?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They must be divided of necessity.

p.hi: Why so?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Because, as four consonants cannot begin a word, so four also cannot begin a syllable in any part of the word.

p.hi: What if a consonant doubled come between two vowels?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
They must be divided, as in dif-fer, the
double (ff) is divided, as you see.

p.hi: But doth this hold always so?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yea, except when the consonant is needlesly doubled, as in some plurals, as barres, plummes, and the like, whereas plums bars, with a single (m o •
r) would serve turn well enough.

p.hi: But may not the syllables of some compounded-words thwart some of these rules:

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea, that they may.

p.hi: Your reason for it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: My reason is; because the simple word when it is compounded, will (for all that) keep the same letters, as when it was simple.

p.hi: Pray instance in some compound-words, that thwart these rules.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will, un-apt,) where the former syllable endeth with a consonant, against this rule. The former syllable cannot end with a consonant, except the latter syllable begin with a consonant. (dis l • ke, where (sl) are divided, though they will begin a word, as (slo-ven.)

p.hi: Do not these and the like derivatives (speak-ing, strength-en-ing,) cross your rules?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Indeed they do, but because it would be troublesome to make new rules for them, we will reckon them (at present) amongst the compounded ones, and so these (like the others) being found in a kind of composition, every word must have it's own letters, not mingled with others.

p.hi: Are there more kinds of such words, besides what you have named?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea, many more, but (for brevity's, sake I shall omit them, onely by the way—

p.hi: What?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That all compound-words, written with (sh, th or ph,) (though these three will begin the word in simple words,) yet found in composition will be divided, thus (hous-hold, priest-hood, up-hold,) and not thus (houshold, priesthood, uphold,) not separating the syllable, and this holds true also in any other of this kinde.

p.hi: But when (i or u,) come betwixt two vowels, what say you to them?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I say, that they are, (especially) (i taken sometimes for dipthongs, when placed with the former syllable: sometimes for consonants when placed with the latter, hence we say Jehoi-adah, or Jeho-jadah.

p.hi: Now you have also pleased me about division of words, both with the vowel or dipthong, between two consonants, and also with the consonant between two vowels: have you any more to say, before you come to the third thing Orthography treateth of?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Any thing more, yea, that I have; but Randolph and Sampson, will say it for me.

div.head: DIALOGUE XLII. Randolph. Sampson. Of some letters that are but a little sounded in the word.

p.hi: SAmpson, in one of the former dialogues, the thirty-ninth as I take it,) Anthony promised some larger discourse of letters, that were little sounded; will you do it at this time?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I will, ask what you please

p.hi: Are all the vowels in some words little sounded?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yes, and some Consonants also.

p.hi: Your example first of the five vowels, beginning with the vowel (a.)

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: When (ea or oa) come together, as earth, wealth, beat, beauty, these with (ea:) boat, coat, moat, abroad, these with (oa,) (a) is little sounded, and here you must take notice that (a,) in these kind of words draweth the syllable long, (as hath been said elsewhere) like (e) in the end of other words.

p.hi: Now let's have an example of (e.)

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: (e) is not pronounced in George, trueth, moneth.

p.hi: In what words is not (i) pronounced?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
In these, shield, field, priest, chief, brief, shrieve, grieve, sieg, maister, their, view, mischief, grief, friese, achieve, marveil, fierce, adieu,
interfier, kerchief, lieutenant, fruit, suit, bruise, b • uit, &c.

p.hi: What words sound not (o?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: These, people, bloud, yeoman, jeopardy.

p.hi: What not (u?)

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Guest, guise, buy, guide, prologue, build, tongue, guilty, conduit, league, plague, &c.

p.hi: Having satisfied me about words that have the vowels not pronounced, what say you to the Consonants, that are not sounded? Pray which are not?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: (b) is not sounded in lamb, comb, debt, bdelium, doubt, dumb, thumb, &c.

p.hi: What else?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: (c) is not sounded (as some will have it) in back, beck, lick, lock, luck, but of that letter enough elsewhere.

p.hi: Are there any other Consonants not, or but little sounded?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yea, (g) in signe, resigne, ensigne, flegme, reigne, soveraigne, Gascoigne.

p.hi: Is (h) also little or nothing at all sounded in some words?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yes, as in Christ myrrhe, whole; Scholar, Eunuch, Chronicles, authority, anchor, choler, chrystal, Rhine, Rhenish, Rhetorick, abhominable, melancholy, also in these proper names, John, Thomas, Achiah, Chinah, Zachariah, Zichri, Chios, Aristarchus, and such as end in (arch) as monarch, &c.

p.hi: What say you of (gh?)

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
I say that it is little sounded in Borrough,
might, bright, sight, &c. so (n) in solemn, condemn, autumn, hymne,

p.hi: What of (p,) and of (s?)
I say that (p) is little sounded in psalm, receipt, accompt, and (s) as little in isle, island, Viscount, Lisle.
Now we have done with letters that are little sounded in words, shall we now speak something of the third thing, orthography treateth of, to wit, right utterance?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Before that can be done, two things (I suppose) must first be toucheth on by the next speakers.

p.hi: What are they?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: First, those that we call abreviations, and secondly, words that are not pronounced as they are written.

div.head: DIALOGUE XLIII. Theophilact. Ambrose. Of Abreviations.

p.hi: HOw do you write Abreviations?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thus, a stroke over any vowel stands for (m or n,) as dā. mā. for dam, man, so yr for your: Mr. for master, Mris. for Mistris, Mrs. for masters: ye for the: yt for that: yu for thou: wt for what: wth for with: wch for which: or for our, &c.

p.hi: Are there not others too?

sp.speaker: A.

p.hi: What if a vowel end a word, and the next word begin with a vowel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The ending vowel is cut off by the vowel that begins the following word, as th' intent, for the intent; I'm, for I am, and many more such-like cuttings off there are, which you may meet with in play-books and poets.

p.hi: Have you now named all the words which you call Abreviations?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, in written-hand you may finde many more, which you may take notice of as you meet with them.

p.hi: Now lastly: shew us some of them that are pronounced otherwise then they are written.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Bartholomew and Gabriel, do ye shew them it.

div.head: DIALOGUE XLIII. Bartholomew. Gabriel. Of words that are not pronounced as they are written.

p.hi: GAbriel, what words are not pronounced as they are written?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: These, (besides qualm, shalt &c. which have been spoken of already in the twentieth Dialogue, besides others spoken of in the thirtieth Dialogue) these I say, (would, could, should) are pronounced (wood, cood shood,) as if so written: so some words that end with (gh,) are pronounced as if wrote with (f,) hence we write laugh pronounce it laf. cough. cof.

p.hi: Are not some with (gh) pronounced otherwise?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, thus, bough, bou, sigh, sieth, thigh, thie, &c.

p.hi: Are not words with (i or o) pronounced sometimes as if wrote with (u?)

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, so shirt, chirp, with (i) work, wort, with (o) sound as if wrote, shurt, churp, wurk wurt, with (u.

p.hi: May we ad more to these?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea many, as iron, which we sound iurm, victuals, vittles, apron, apurn; mutton, fasten, as muttne fastne; so words in ed, as beloved, delivered, we sound belov'd, deliver'd, so wont as woont, subtilo as suttle, epistle as episle, tongue, as tong schedule as sedule, schismatick as sizmatick, bloud, as blud, people as peeple, shovel, as shuul, conie as kunnee, discretion, (to name no more) as d screshon.

p.hi: By all these examples a man may plainly sée that there is great difference betwixt the speaking and the writing of some english words.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea truly so a man may.

p.hi: Can you give us more of these?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That I can, but I shall referre you to a book which is to this purpose of Mr. Hodges's as I take it.

p.hi: Well said, now I sée that according to the latine-saying, scribendum ad doctos, loquendum ad vulgus, we must write as the priest, but speak as the people.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: You are in the right, now 'tis high-time to come to the third thing Orthography treateth of, to wit, right utterance.

p.hi: 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And with all my heart I would undertake it, but that I know (for certain,) that the two next will handle it for us.

div.head: DIALOGUE XXXXV. Josuah. Moses. Of Right-utterance.

p.hi: MOses, what is right utterance?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Right utterance is the manner of right speaking out.

p.hi: May not boys by speaking too fast, or too slow, and by other usual faults in pronouncing offend many ways?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea many ways, but especially three wayes.

p.hi: By what way first?

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: By a Traulism, which is when one stammereth or stuttereth as babababy for baby.

p.hi: How is that fault amended?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: By pattering over some ribble-rable made hard to pronounce, one purpose: as, Arx tridens rostris sphinx prester torrida seps strix.

p.hi: By what way next?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: By a Plateasme, which is when one speaketh too broad; as yow for you (the country-man's fault.)

p.hi: What corrupt pronountiation else do such kind of men use?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: This, mell hell for mill hill, knat for knit, belk for belch, to spat for to spit, sur suster, for sir sister, leash for lease, certen or sarten, for certain, kerchar for carchief, parfit for perfect, sample for example, stomp for stamp, gurt for girth, griffe for graffe, yelk for yolk, yerb for herb, bredg for bridg, knat for gnat, and a thousand more of such like corrupt kind of speakings have they, which I shall pass by, giving you onely here a taste (as it were) of them.

p.hi: Do they not also oft-times use (f) for v,) and v for f?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea; saying feal for veal, and vather for father, and the like.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They say a nox, my naunt; for an ox, mine Aunt.

p.hi: What more?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The northernly folk pronounce (ed like it) pleadit, intendit, unitit, belovit, for pleaded, intended, united, beloved: also gid and gad, for good and god: leard for lord, also the scots say, mercat, for market, wes for was, publict for publick, wer on lyff, for were alive: swa that likewayes, for so that likewise, and there be many others which I shall omit.

p.hi: What else?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Some also put (e for i) as pietee for pietie, and some write or say a cup a wine, for a cup of wine, and other like absurdities.

p.hi: But may we not (writing to our countrey-friend) make use of our countrey-terms?

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: You may, so that they be peculiar terms, and such as do not corrupt words; so the northern-man may write such termes as these to his friend or country-man: lathe for barn, bern for childe, kirk for church, garth for yard, sark for shirt, and the like.

p.hi: What should he or any do, if they should write publikely?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Truly, use the most usual and known termes.

p.hi: Come we now to the third; which is called Ichnotes: and what is that?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It is, when one speaketh, either. 1 too-mincingly; as weter for water, lerd for lard, a strea for a straw, that is; sounding (e for a) or
2 to lispingly, as cannoth for cannot, sounding (th) for (t,) and the like, the citizen's fault.

p.hi: Now, the last thing Orthrography treateth of?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That, the two last, Sylvester and Bromfield will satisfie you to the full in.

div.head: DIALOGUE XLVI. Sylvester. Bromfield. Of the Points of Sentences.

p.hi: BRomfield, what is a Point or Pause, which is used in distinguishing writing?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A point or pause is a note of distinction, signifying the space of breathing, or how long one may stay ones breath.

p.hi: Are there not many of these Points, or Pauses?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: There are, especially eight are worth the noting.

p.hi: What call you the first?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Comma, which is a short pause, distinguishing the shorter parts of the sentence, and is marked thus—(,)

p.hi: What call you the second?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Semicolon, which stays a sentence longer than a Comma, though not so long as a Colon, and is marked thus—(;)

p.hi: What call you the third?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Colon, which is a longer stay, dividing the sentence (as it were) in the midst, and is marked thus— (:)

p.hi: What the fourth?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A Period, which (being placed at the end of a sentence) makes a full stay or stop, and is marked thus—(.)

p.hi: The fifth, what is it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Parenthesis, which is used to enclose such words as may be left out, and yet the sentence will be perfect, and is marked thus—()

p.hi: The sixth, what is it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The Interrogation point, which is onely used when a question is asked, and usually requires a full stop, and is marked thus—(?)

p.hi: What's the seventh?

sp.speaker: B
sp.p: The Admiration point, (called also the note of Exclamation) which is used with a kinde of wondering, being also a full stop, and is marked thus— (!)

p.hi: The eighth or last, what is it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Hyphen, which is a little stroke interposed, either 1 in a word divided at the end of a line: as Tho mas; or 2 is used in words that are united, but not compounded; as blood-sucking, King-killing, Common-wealth.

p.hi: Now you have shew'd us all the eight points, Honest Bromfield wi • l you now give us examples of them all out of the Scripture?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I will, if you please.

p.hi: First then, let's hear a Scripture-sentence with a comma in it—,

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You shall: I exhort therefore, that first of all, supp •• cat • ons, prayers, intercessions, and giving of thanks be made for all men, for kings, &c. 1 Tim. chap. 2. verse 1, 2.

p.hi: Now one with a semicolon.—;

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: My sonne, fear thou the Lord and the king; &c. Prov. chap. 24. verse 21.

p.hi: Now one with a colon.—:

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Let every soul be subject to the higher Powers: &c. Rom chap. 13. verse 1.

p.hi: One also with a period.— (.)

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Honor all men. Love the brother-hood. Fear God. Honor the King. 1 Peter, chap. 2. verse 17.

p.hi: In what verse finde you a parenthesis?— ()

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: And all this assembly shall know that the Lord saveth not with sword and spear (for the battel is the Lords) 1 Sam. 17 47.

p.hi: In what is the Interrogation point?—(!)

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Where the word of a king is, there is power: and who may say unto him, What dost thou? Eccles 8 4.

p.hi: The Admiration point—!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable
are his judgements, and his ways past finding out! Rom. 11.33.

p.hi: To draw to a conclusion (both of this Dialogue, as also of the whole Book) shew me Hyphen —(-) and I have done.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Love the brother-hood: this word brother hood makes good what I have said. And now (Sylvester) we have run through all the things Orthography treateth of, to wit, 1 Letters. 2 Syllables. (to which were added words) 3 Right utterance. 4 Points of sentences.

div.p: D • alogue 13. page 22. for (before three dipthongs) read (before the dipthong) Dial. 18. p. 33. for (that begins with (hh) read (that begins with (Rh). Dialogue 21. p. 45. for two, read too. Dial. 34. p 82. for (re, ce, cno, read re, ce, con. Dial. 36. p. 88. accent aver're, &c. also p. 90. accent, To excu'se, an ex'cuse, &c. also for to use, read to vze a vse. Dial. 37. p. 94. blot out way. and in p. 95. for Knok our boy, read Knox.
O • her faults, which remain behind; I pray thee, (gentle Reader,) to mark, and amend them.
